Memorandum:

MR. BAILEY

I attach account covering the cost of linoleum purchased for use in the vocational training room at the Caughnawaga R.C. School. There was no covering on the floor of this room, which is located in the basement, and during the cold weather the staff and pupils were considerably inconvenienced. The agent, therefore, was authorized to purchase the quantity of linoleum necessary to cover the floor of this room.

I should appreciate it if you would issue purchase order so that the account may be paid. The coding is as follows: 76-305-12-415.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Feb. 24 To alterations and repairs made to the electric wiring system at the Caughnawaga Senior School, as per tender submitted. $945.00
Caughnawaga, January 3rd, 1941.

Dear Sir,

I beg to transmit you herewith an account amounting to $945.00 in favour of Isadie Garand, Electrician of Chateauguay Bassin for alterations and repairs to the electric wiring system at the Caughnawaga Senior School as per tender submitted in the course of June last.

The delay in submitting this account is due to the fact that the acceptance certificate from the Board of Examiners of Electricians only reached this office a few days ago.

I would kindly recommend the payment of the enclosed account as the work is now terminated and seems to be very satisfactory.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, June 5, 1941.

Dear Sir:

It is my understanding that arrangements have been made whereby the weaving class at the Caughnawaga School will continue in operation during the regular summer holiday period.

This class will be under the direction of Miss G. Foisy, who has been for a number of years in charge of one of our Indian day schools at the St. Regis Reserve.

The Sister Superior has communicated with me in respect to the caretaking of the school during this period. The Sisters are naturally anxious that the property and equipment of the school should be under responsible supervision during their absence. Please discuss the matter of caretaking with Mr. Robert and reach an agreement with him whereby he will give the school and school buildings the supervision that may be necessary during the summer months. The Sister Superior has intimated that the caretaker may expect additional remuneration for this work. I must inform you, however, that it is not the intention of the Department to pay for this additional service, and you should so inform Mr. Robert. In addition to the supervision that may be given by Mr. Robert, it would be appreciated if during the holiday period you would visit the school from time to time and assure yourself that the property and equipment are not being injured in any way.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Mr. F. Brisebois,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, Que.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

May we be authorized to spend $75.00 for the Sewing Class and $100.00 for the Domestic Science Class of the Caughnawage R. C. Indian Day School? CAUGHNAWAGA FIRE DESTROYS SCHOOL

Montreal and Lachine Departments Help Battle Blaze

(Special to The Gazette)
Caughnawaga, Que., December 19.—Swept by fire which started shortly before midnight, the Senior School building at Caughnawaga here appeared to be a total loss early today. Firemen from both the Jorts of Montreal and Lachine fire department came to the scene in aid of this Indian Reserve which is a well-known reservation.

Indian Agent Mr. X. Briarbois, with John K. Jocks, summoned aid of the nearby fire department of Montreal when it appeared that the flames were spreading. Firemen went through a number of residences near the school to try to stop the wind.

Shortly before 1 a.m., Mr. Briarbois reported that the Lachine department had brought a load of Chief Angus Mickie had succeeded in obtaining water from the St. Lawrence River and was now attacking the blaze which had moved through the school, a two-story brick building attended by about 200 pupils. The Montreal fire department arrived at about that time and joined the forces engaged to attack the blaze under orders of Chief Angus Mickie.

The doomed school was valued at about $45,000, the resident agent said.

A strong wind forced the flames to sweep the school and an attempt after the fire was discovered by Albert Jocks to extinguish them.

Until the arrival of the firemen, a bucket brigade was engaged in fighting the fire which apparently broke out in the furnace room.

Dear Sir;-

I beg to refer to my previous telephone calls to Ottawa in which I informed you of the destruction by fire of the local Senior School and in this connection to make the following report.

At about 11.30 P.M., the janitor who was living at the School was awakened by the smoke. Upon opening the door of his room which leads to the furnace room he saw some flame which appeared to him to be in the corridor between the sewing class room and the door leading to the furnace room. As he tried to reach for the fire extinguishers he was overcome by smoke and had to get out of the building. He then ran to the Church and gave the alarm. A few minutes after a bucket brigade went and tried to fight the fire but it was useless.

I was awakened by a neighbor and immediately went to the office and called for the Lachine and Montreal firemen. The Lachine brigade came at about 12.30 and the Montreal firemen about 20 minutes later. It was however too late to save the School as the fire had spread to the three floors and was activated by a strong west wind. At about three o'clock the whole building collapsed.

The fire was blowing directly on the Kateri School and a wooden house located back of it. In fact the firemen had to concentrate their efforts at the other building and often had to turn the water on the Katheri School which was saved owing to their presence. Other fires also started but were promptly put out. The Village was threatened up to the time of the collapse of the School. The firemen worked with two powerful pumps from the time of their arrival up to nine o'clock in the morning.

School At Reservation Burns Down

Flames Threaten Indian Community as Lachine And City Rush Help

Other Outbreaks

Completely destroyed by a fire which started shortly before midnight, the School School of the St. Francis Mission in Caughnawaga was a mass of ruins at dawn today, with firemen standing guard over the smouldering remnants. Damage was estimated at more than $60,000.

Montreal and Lachine firemen, with Chief Angus MacKie, Pierre, rushed to the scene upon urgent call of Inspector Pierre Brisebois. It appeared that the blaze, fanned by a strong wind, would sweep through the rest of the buildings near the school. The Indian Reserve, which is without fire protection, was first ordered to fight the blaze with a "bucket brigade."

The alarm was sounded by the janitor of the three-storey wood and brick building. Firemen rushed up to find smoke and fire surrounding him. Overcome by dense smoke, he was recovered in time to escape from the inferno and save Mr. Brisebois.

FRANKLIN FIREMEN

The Lachine Department under Chief Angus MacKie obtained water from the Lachine river and pumped it into the blaze, having succeeded in stemming the fire somewhat when the arrival of Montreal firemen, under Chief Maclean, was heard.

Mr. Brisebois said the doomed school, built in 1893 by the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, was attended by 200 children of the reserve. He praised the efficient work of the firemen from Montreal and Lachine, without whose prompt action the engulfed most of the reservation might have been destroyed.

Fire Inspector Pare, of Montreal, kept in constant touch with the progress of the fire, stating this morning that his men would remain on the scene until after nine o'clock.

Three firemen were hurt while battling the flames and caused damage to a one-storey building on Laguerre street west, with its contents.

The blaze, discovered at 2:45 a.m., began to grow at 3:30 a.m. at 300 Fehr at 992 Laguerre street. The flames later spread to the nearby machines of D. Kingley, 990 Laguerre street.

District Chief Heaney and his men, assisted by Director Roche, managed to quell the fire an hour later. Smaller fires were also managed the premises of the Union Garage, 895 Cathedral street, located in the basement, as well as the premises of J. O. Lefebvre.

The injured were Lt. H. Hammond and J. Cloran, both of No. 25, and J. Chamberlain of No. 5 station who received slight cuts from the flames from broken glass. Damage of $15,000 was caused at 559 Haig street at an early hour; this fire, whose cause of unknown origin broke out in the window of the second floor of the house, spread to both the lower and upper flats.

Firemen from Lebel Bourdon played two streams of water into the blaze, which started at about 2:30 a.m. and was fully extinguished an hour later.
CAUGHNAWAGA FIRE DESTROYS SCHOOL

Montreal and Lachine Departments Help Battle Blaze

(Special to The Gazette.)

Caughnawaga, Que., December 13—Shortly before midnight, the Senior School of the St. Francis Mission near Caughnawaga was destroyed early this morning despite the efforts of Montreal and Lachine firemen who rushed to the aid of this Indian Reserve which is situated near the town.

Indian Agent F. X. Brisebois, with John Robert, chief of police of the nearby municipality and of Montreal firemen, tried to prevent the flames from possibly sweeping through the houses of the Indians near the school due to a strong wind.

Shortly before 1 a.m., Mr. Brisebois informed the Montreal Fire Department under command of Chief Angus Mickie had succeeded in obtaining water from the St. Lawrence River and pumping it to attack the fire. The fire had already spread through the three-story wood and brick building which housed about 250 reservation children. The Montreal firemen arrived at the scene about that time and immediately prepared an air force of 16 men under Fire Chief Mechanic Joseph Forget.

The damage caused by the fire is estimated at about $45,000 the resident agent said.

A strong wind forced the flames toward the school yard an hour after the fire was discovered by Albert Robert, the school janitor. Until the firemen arrived on the scene, a bucket brigade failed to cope with the fire when another fire quickly broke out in the furnace room.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Senior School, Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Quebec.

With reference to your notation dated the 20th ultimo on Dr. McGill's memorandum of the same date, and further to our telephone discussion regarding an inspection of the above, I may say that in accordance with Dr. McGill's request, an inspection was carried out by our Architect on the 25th ultimo, and Mr. Buck now reports as follows:

The building known as the senior school was a brick veneered structure, containing partial basement, first, second and third floors. The partial basement housed the heating equipment and water supply system. The first floor contained accommodation for weaving and handicraft work, a domestic science room, the upper portion of boiler and fuel rooms, caretaker's room and one academic class-room, as well as pupils' toilet accommodation. The second floor was assigned completely to classrooms, and an assembly hall occupied the whole top floor area.

The second and third floor construction was carried on a partial steel frame running longitudinally, while the cross bearing was taken by the brick veneered walls. Except for the area occupied by the partial basement, the first floor rested on the ground. Concrete piers in the first floor provided support for steel columns in the upper floors.

On his inspection Mr. Buck found that except for the chimney, which still stands, the building has collapsed during the fire, and that no visible portion of the former structure or its members could be re-used. Those portions of the foundation walls which still remain in position are covered by the ruins, and no definite opinion on their condition will be possible until they have been exposed to view. It is considered likely, however, that the intense heat to which they have been subjected will have destroyed their usefulness.

Interior steel work, such as beams, columns, radiators and heating pipes have been rendered useless by their collapse into the centre of the fire at its height, while exterior fire escape having been carried outward when the exterior walls collapsed, are warped and distorted beyond repair.

No metal.....

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
No metal work that could be seen is considered to have any value beyond what might be obtained for scrap.

Since the former boiler room is completely filled with debris to grade level, it was not possible to inspect the two heating boilers, fuel oil pump, fuel oil tank or water supply equipment. It is considered unlikely that this equipment could be reused, but under existing building conditions it should be inspected before being disposed of.

The chimney remains standing, but its condition is hazardous and the Indian Affairs Branch should arrange for its demolition immediately.

It was observed that among the debris there are some undamaged face brick; but the cost of sorting, cleaning and stacking them for re-use would not be justified.

It is felt that a better price for salvageable scrap metal could be obtained by disposing of it separately, rather than by asking for an allowance when considering new construction work, and on this basis the following action is recommended:

(a) That the existing chimney be demolished immediately under the supervision of the Indian Agent.

(b) That the Indian Agent be instructed to have the former boiler room cleared of all debris, to uncover heating boilers, fuel pump, water supply equipment etc., for the convenience of Departmental officers on inspection, or parties tendering on scrap materials.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Fire at Senior School, Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Quebec.

With reference to the recent destruction of the above school by fire, I may say that during a discussion on the matter preceding his inspection on the 29th ultimo our architect was requested by Indian Affairs officers to establish if possible the cause of the fire.

It is understood that the responsibility of determining the cause of fires rests with the officer in charge of the Agency; but in discussing the matter with the Indian Agent, I may say that our architect obtained information as follows:

The fire was discovered to be raging in the central hall on the first floor, shortly after midnight December 16th, 1941. At the time of discovery it had made such headway that it was only with great difficulty that the caretaker Mr. Robert who lived in the building, was able to escape.

He reached the village church in night attire and sounded the alarm before he was overcome by the effects of smoke.

The caretaker was unable to give a coherent account of his discovery of the fire; but Mr. Brisebois, the agent, stated that by the time he arrived at the school the fire had reached such proportions that it was obvious that nothing more than preventing the spread of the conflagration was possible.

In his opinion the strong wind was threatening to carry burning embers over the whole village area, and several small blazes were observed in the vicinity.

Mr. Brisebois summoned fire-fighting apparatus from Montreal and Lachine, and both brigades responded.

The services of two pumpers and crews were required until approximately 5 a.m. December 19th, when the fire was considered definitely under control.

The fire had made such headway before discovery, and wrought such complete destruction upon the building, that it is not considered possible to establish the cause.

Respectfully submitted,

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa,
Ontario.

While in Montreal last week, I called at the City Hall regarding a charge of $1043.33 made by the City for services rendered on December 19, 1941, when our school was destroyed by fire.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Caughnawaga R.C. School

On the night of the destruction by fire of the senior school there was a very heavy wind blowing and, as the buildings in the village are quite close together, Indian Agent Brisebois was afraid that the whole village might be burned. Consequently he phoned the fire departments at Lachine, Quebec, and at Montreal, Quebec, requesting them to forward fire-fighting equipment. Both of them responded. In reporting his action in the above regard the Indian Agent wrote as follows:

"I was awakened by a neighbour and immediately went to the office and called for the Lachine and Montreal firemen. The Lachine brigade came at about 12:30 and the Montreal firemen about 20 minutes later. It was, however, too late to save the school as the fire had spread to the three floors and was activated by a strong west wind. At about three o'clock the whole building collapsed.

"The fire was blowing directly on the Kateri School and a wooden house located back of it. In fact the firemen had to concentrate their efforts at the other building and often had to turn the water on the Kateri School which was saved owing to their presence. Other fires also started but were promptly put out. The village was threatened up to the time of the collapse of the school. The firemen worked with two powerful pumps from the time of their arrival up to nine o'clock in the morning."
Recently the following accounts have been submitted for payment for the firemen's services:

City of Montreal - $1,043.33
City of Lachine - $500.00

Inspector Thibault was instructed to call at the Montreal City Hall with a view to having their charge reduced. He was unsuccessful in this regard, his report reading as follows:

"While in Montreal last week, I called at the City Hall regarding a charge of $1,043.33 made by the City for services rendered on December 19, 1941, when our school was destroyed by fire.

"The rate of $100.00 per hour is set for all similar calls to municipalities outside of city limits, with a minimum of $150.00.

"Such rate is including the extra insurance on firemen on duty outside of the city limits, the risk of damage to equipment travelling for service to non-taxpayers, such equipment valued at over $30,000.00.

"According to information received, the presence of the Montreal fire brigade certainly prevented a more serious conflagration, due to the high wind during that night, and saved many Indian homes as well as our other school nearby, which was, for a while, in a rather dangerous spot."

We are endeavouring to have the Caughnawaga Indian Council pass a resolution approving payment of at least half of the account from their band funds. The other half can be met from the appropriation for Indian education. If the band refuses to pass the resolution, it will be necessary to take the whole amount from the
Indian education appropriation. I should appreciate receiving the approval of the Minister.

Director.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to the accounts submitted by the City of Montreal and the City of Lachine amounting to $1,543.33 for fire protection at Caughnawaga on the night of December 19, 1941.

While the work done by the firemen no doubt prevented the destruction of the Kateri School, at the same time there is no question that their efforts also prevented the spread of the fire throughout the Village of Caughnawaga. As a result the Department feels that part of the expense should be paid from band funds. It is suggested that the band should meet half the expenditure and the balance will be paid from Parliamentary appropriation.

If, however, they are not willing to meet half the cost at least a large portion of this should be provided from band funds.

Please take up this matter at the next meeting of the Council and secure the required resolution.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,

Chief Commissioner Peter Lazarus
Dear Sir;-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th ultimo dealing with the accounts submitted by the City of Montreal and that of Lachine amounting to $1,543.33 for fire protection at Caughnawaga on the night of December 19, 1941.

As requested the matter of having part of the above accounts paid from the Band funds was taken up with the Council at the March meeting which was held on the 5th instant and in this connection I beg to enclose herewith resolution no.1071, in which the Council is refusing to pay any portion of that account. Their action is much regretted and is clearly showing their non-cooperative attitude.

In the course of the discussion the councillors claimed that the building destroyed was the property of the Government and as no Indian property was affected by the fire they could not see why they should be called upon to contribute towards the paying of the accounts.

When it was pointed out that had it not been for the presence of the firemen a conflagration would have taken place and a portion of the Village destroyed, no reply could be obtained. They only reiterated their intention not to pay any amount.

Yours very truly,

R.A.Hoey, Esq.,
Supt., of Welfare and Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Indian Agent
Dear Sir:

I was very much concerned when I learned recently that apparently the doors of the schools at Caughnawaga are kept locked during school hours. It has been stated that the doors are locked at nine o'clock and that any pupils who come late have to return home. I do not approve of this latter action but, in any case, the doors should be kept unlocked whenever the classrooms are occupied. Locking the doors of the classrooms during school hours is a very definite fire hazard and cannot be permitted under any circumstances.

I also understand that fire drills have not been practised at regular intervals. One excuse given was that the fire escapes were dangerous on account of ice accumulating in some spots. In view of the destruction of the senior school, the caretakers certainly cannot be overworked and there is no reason why the fire escapes should not be kept clear of snow and ice. Please see that this is done in future and at the same time arrange to have fire drills conducted regularly.

Both the above matters should be brought to the attention of the Rev. Principal at once.

Yours truly,

Mr. F. Brisebois,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, Que.

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT a fire occurred at the Caughnawaga R.C. Indian Day School on the night of December 18, 1941;

THAT funds for payment of the above accounts are available in the appropriation for the current fiscal year.

Dear Sir;-

I have your letter of the 17th instant dealing with school matters at Caughnawaga and more especially of the locking of the doors during the school hours and the practice of firedrills at regular intervals.

In reply I wish to inform that these matters have been taken up with the Superior who assured that the front doors will be kept opened during the school hours. Dear Mr. Roy,

I was advised by the Agent Bureau of your letter concerning our schools. Doors locked and no one drilled. May I explain this real situation and the reasons thereof not to become justified by my way of acting but simply to make things clear to you.

You do so understand matters known. The Indian School in the village, the front door is never locked during school hours. As to the Boys' Eastern school, yes, we have kept the doors locked after 9 and often 10 o'clock for this reason. There are certain troubles liable, including a neighbor who has come into the school in an unfit condition and the teachers had difficulty in getting them out. Moreover, the...
teachers and pupils were afraid of these very intruders... so I said the teachers locked the pupils shut the doors would be locked for that reason but that if they came in late all that was to be done was to eat at the side doors and a bell always rings the door. The well thinking people here have understood this bell those boys who are not anxious to be out make no effort whatever to be on time nor to find means of getting in even after school hours. Some parents have spoken to me of this matter and have understood very well... even helping us by seeing their boys get to school on time. So to the well thinking people those boys come in late regardless of school hours.

Nevertheless we shall keep all doors unlocked since you liked this done. The above mentioned measure has been taken to keep order in school as well as somewhat forcing the boys to get to school on time. At this Reserve school started at 12 o'clock some would come in at 12:30... the mentality same is there... I trust Mr. Roy that this fact is well understood - I cannot well see a wanted order and discipline will kept in our schools but with the doors unlocked at the Boys' School we will face the same difficulties even the fact. We will nevertheless
able by your orders.

As to fire drills we did not have any during the winter months. I did not insist on having the fire escapes closed or extinguishing the fire every day, for I must very sincerely tell you that it would have been useless to try... Since the ice has disappeared, we have had such drills and intend doing so in the future.

Hoping that you will understand my rule of action here and that it is the advancement of our school interests both for the instruction and for the education of our Indian boys and girls.

Very sincerely yours,

Rev. Mary Jean de Fave,
Principal

Dear Sir:

The fire brigade of the Town of St-Pierre got to the Reserve on that night, not on the request of this office, but apparently after having received telephone calls from residents of Caughnawaga and of Lady Rodick who had been informed by telephone that the whole village was on fire.

The firemen did not do any work on that occasion as the fire was under control and that the Montreal and Lachine brigades were already working. I understand however that some damage was made to their pump when going back to St-Pierre.

Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle

Re: Senior School Fire - Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Quebec.

With regard to your notation dated February 2nd last, on a memorandum from Dr. McGill dated January 30th, 1942, you will recall that more pressing work prevented our officers from carrying out an inspection as requested by Dr. McGill at that time.

Arrangements were made, however, for our Architect to visit the Agency on the 27th ultimo, at which time he inspected the former boiler room in the school, and was able to determine that the two small heating boilers and other visible units of equipment are no longer serviceable, and of no use for incorporation in a new building.

In connection with units formerly embodied in the heating system, a fuel oil storage tank of 1000 gallons capacity was installed about eight years ago below grade immediately outside the building. It is understood that at the time of the fire this tank contained considerable fuel oil. While neither the tank nor its connections to the system could be inspected, to establish whether or not the contents had been ignited during the fire, it is considered that these should not be re-installed in a new building.

It is therefore recommended that the Indian Affairs Branch take the necessary action to dispose of all metals and other materials to the best advantage.

It was observed during the inspection, that the isolated chimney had been demolished, as previously recommended by this Service; but it is further recommended that, upon completion of salvage operations, the Indian Affairs Branch arrange for the covering or filling of the basement cavity, to eliminate hazard to the children of the village.

Respectfully submitted,

Chief Engineer.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Caughnawaga, July 7, 1942.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Sometime ago, I wrote you asking your approval of the purchase of a linoleum for the Community Room, where our school children have been lodged since the Senior School Fire.

I am well aware that this request should have preceded the purchase of said linoleum but as the opportunity was offered me of a very fine linoleum at the low rate of $1.00 per sq. yd and as I did presume your permission, purchased it at the cost of $48.

Since no answer came to me, I concluded that this act did not meet with your approval since, I do admit, it was not done according to the right procedure. I am frank with you in stating this. I found the opportunity so favorable that I did not hesitate to expect a favorable approval from you.

May I ask you now, to appropriate half this expense, that is $24.00 towards this linoleum and I will carry over the balance myself, thus atoning for my forward act.

With sincere hope that you will consider my present request, I am

Most sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Principal.

Ottawa, July 13, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, in reference to the grates and bottom door for the furnace in the Caughnawaga teacher's residence. I wish you would make some enquiries in Montreal and ascertain if you can secure the necessary grates there. If so, you should state the name of the firm from whom they can be obtained and the approximate cost.

I would like to know, also, what size of coal will be required. I presume it will be stove size but would like definite assurance in this regard and also the number of tons that you consider would be needed.

There is still a possibility of our securing oil, but, if we cannot do so, we will of course have to use coal. For this reason I am requesting the information mentioned in the first part of this letter and would appreciate receiving it as soon as possible. I expect a definite decision regarding the oil by the end of this week, and, in the event of our not securing the oil, I want to have the necessary information to secure the coal as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. F. Brisebois,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, Que.

Teachers' Residence,
Caughnawaga, July 23, 1942.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

As you are aware, Nurse Piquette left the Caughnawaga Reserve last week to establish her home in Gaspé.

While paying us a farewell visit, she asked if we would be interested in the purchase of her piano which is now at Constable Jack's home. She would be willing to dispose of it for the very reasonable sum of $40.00. The piano is in fine condition.

We are writing this letter to ask you if you would authorize the purchase of this piano for Eastern School, to be used for Physical Culture Exercises. We would certainly appreciate having one. We had taken up the matter of buying a second-hand piano with Mr. Doucet shortly after the Senior School Fire and he had promised to do something as a very good piano had been offered him a few days before. We heard no more about it but now feel this opportunity too good, so let it pass. Since the piano is already on the Reserve, the matter of transportation can be very easily arranged.

May we expect a favorable answer before long? We thank you again for this and for other past favors.

Very respectfully yours,

SISTERS OF SAINT ANN

Principal.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Ottawa.

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent, Caughnawaga, Que.

The Department finds it necessary to return your voucher No. 506 covering electricity supplied for the lighting of the Caughnawaga Village Schools.

Before payment of the account can be made very explicit explanations will have to be given regarding the "Adjusting" bills included in the account. Several of the accounts do not show the past and present readings. These will have to be supplied except, of course, in the case of those where there is a minimum charge.

I also find that the October account for the Eastern School was not forwarded when you sent the other accounts for that month under cover of your voucher No. 446.

The Company must realize that we wish these accounts submitted every month and as they read the meters we cannot understand why adjustment bills have to be forwarded later.

We do not want this matter to assume the proportions that it did in 1935 when we were obliged to check accounts back for several months due to the fact that the Company's meter readers had read meters incorrectly. I trust that you will find it possible to have this account adjusted at an early date and complete information, as requested above, forwarded.

Caughnawaga, January 8th, 1943.

Mr. R.A. Hoey, Supt. of Welfare, Indian Affairs Branch.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 31st ultimo, returning voucher No. 506 covering electricity supplied for the lighting of the Caughnawaga Village Schools, requesting very explicit explanations before payment can be made.

In reply I wish to inform you that on receipt of the account for October, it was noticed that the account usually amounting to $3.00 or $4.00 was of $16.35. An electrician was called to inspect the wiring as a short circuit was suspected. The short circuit was found, and the matter was taken up by this office with the Shawinigan Water & Power Co., at Valleyfield, in order to obtain an adjustment. The result was that the Company agreed to adjust the bills for October and November at the amount of $4.96, per month, therefore, my submitting said accounts.

I am also sending you copies of the accounts for October and November, from which it was deducted that the wiring system was short circuit. Voucher No. 506 is returned herewith.

I hope the above explanations will be found satisfactory to the Branch.

Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

In the course of last year instruction had been received to ask for tenders for the brick etc., on the site of the Senior School at Caughnawaga which was destroyed by fire in December 1941.

At the time no one was interested. Those who were approached claimed that to undertake the removal of the broken brick etc., would be too expensive and that the good material left was not worth the cost of the cleaning of the site.

However lately I received two prices for the material left. One from Mr. A. Groulx 2286 Albert st., Montreal, for $100.00 and another from Mr. J. Fortunat Crepin of Chateauguay Basin for $105.00. Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: Caughnawaga Indian Day School

In official memorandum of April 27, 1942, you were advised of a considerable quantity of material available for salvage as a result of the destruction of the above school by fire. In your memorandum of April 30, File 20 I.A. - P.Q., you authorized the Indian Agent to obtain quotations and he subsequently sold a quantity of steel and old iron as authorized by Salvage Minute 19756 dated June 26, 1942.

I am now advised by Indian Agent Brisebois that there is a quantity of brick on the site of the former school, but last year no one was interested in purchasing it. Those who were approached at that time claimed that to remove the broken brick etc. would be too expensive and that the good material left was not worth the cost of cleaning the site.

Recently, however, Mr. Brisebois received two tenders for the material left, one from Mr. A. Groulx, 2288 Albert Street, Montreal, for $100.00, and one from Mr. J.F. Crepin, Chateauguay Basin, for $107.00. I enclose the quotations from these two men and, if you approve selling the old brick to Mr. Crepin, I should appreciate it if you would let me know as soon as possible.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

I am in receipt of your memorandum of August 3, with reference to the account recently submitted to you covering the cost of electrical and plumbing fixtures supplied to the Caughnawaga R.C. Senior School.

As you are aware, the senior school at Caughnawaga was destroyed by fire in December, 1941, and, as a result, the special cooking and sewing room was not available. Early this spring the Indian Agent and the Principal of the Caughnawaga School urged on the Department the necessity of providing suitable rooms in order that cooking and sewing could be taught. The only room available was one in the basement of one of the remaining schools on the reserve and authority was given to install the necessary equipment. It was not convenient to estimate exactly what was required before the work was done and, therefore, the Indian Agent was instructed to employ a competent firm to do the necessary work. Mr. Brisebois certifies that only the necessary equipment was placed in the rooms and I, therefore, feel that the items shown on the account were required in order to provide suitable equipment.

Director.

Re: Steam Heating systems Eastern and Kateri Schools.

Dear Sir:

Further to a survey on the Heating systems of the above mentioned schools, I am pleased to give you a report on the improvements to be made.

The main reason for improper functioning of these systems is that both buildings have sunk into the ground unevenly thus reversing the slopes of most of the radiators and mains.

Secondly, the lacking of traps on all radiators.

As all pipes, radiators and furnaces are still in good condition, may I suggest the following improvements for the proper functioning of both heating systems.

1- Change the one pipe system to a two pipe system by adding returns to all radiators.

2- Add traps to all radiators.

3- Drain the mains by a float trap.

4- Install an automatic pump and receiver.

5- Give the proper slope, a minimum of one half inch in ten feet to all radiators and pipes.

6- Put an insulation wrapping on the furnace and mains.

The estimated costs including labor and all materials except insulation are:

Eastern School, . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . $1224.80

Kateri. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . $1286.00

Mr. Richard's report and suggestion is herewith enclosed. You will note that in the past years too much coal was used at these two Schools and it is believed that in the event of having the necessary repairs made an average of 10 tons of coal per School per year could be saved in a normal winter.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEK

When in Montreal last week at the time of my visit to the Caughnawaga Reserve I also interviewed the Mother General of the Sisters of Ste. Ann, Sister Leopoldine, at the Mother House at Lachine. As you suggested, I discussed with her the possibility of having the Sisters of Ste. Ann erect a new residence for the Nuns teaching the Caughnawaga R.C. School instead of having this building provided by this Department.

As we agreed, I advised her that the Department would be prepared to consider increasing the salaries of the Sisters teaching at Caughnawaga by an amount of $3000.00 a year, if the Order of Ste. Ann would erect the residence at their own expense.

Sister Leopoldine was unable to give me a definite reply, but she appeared to be very much interested in the proposal, as she realizes, as we do, the great necessity for providing proper living accommodation for these Sisters. You know the condition of the building at present in use and something will have to be done in the near future in order to provide suitable living accommodation.

I gathered from Sister Leopoldine's conversation that she was prepared to recommend this action to her Board. She asked if we would be prepared to provide, free of charge, a site for such a building on the reserve. In this regard I advised her that I thought the Department would be favourably disposed to
allow the residence to be built on part of the property of the former senior school. There is plenty of land available for this purpose and, if the residence were built on this site, water and sewage facilities would be available.

Sister Leopoldine said she would discuss the matter with her Board and advise us at some future date regarding their decision.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

With reference to your memorandum of October 9, regarding the type of school building that should replace the Caughnawaga Senior School, I submit the following report:

I visited the Caughnawaga Reserve on October 29 and 30 and discussed school matters generally with Indian Agent Brisebois, Mr. A.E. Wescott, Inspector of Schools, and Sister Mary George. The following is the information specifically requested in your memorandum:

1. As you are aware, the Catholic school at Caughnawaga used three buildings known as the "Eastern", "Kateri" and "Senior" Schools. The latter was destroyed by fire on December 18, 1941. With regard to the Eastern and Kateri Schools, each contains four classrooms and has a full basement. Each classroom can accommodate from 30 to 45 pupils. However, following the fire it was necessary to provide extra classrooms and a temporary partition was erected in each of the two classrooms on the ground floor of each building and consequently there are at the present time twelve classrooms in use. The woodworking class for the boys is in the basement of the Eastern School and the kitchen and sewing room for the girls are in the basement of the Kateri School. On October 29 there was a total enrolment of 322 pupils — 175 boys and 147 girls. For various reasons approximately 28 pupils had not yet registered. They were expected to attend school by the 15th of November which would mean a total of 350 for the current academic year.

2. There is no doubt that the best site for the new school is on the former site of the Senior School. We have plenty of land available and, besides, there is a deep well available for water and there are sewage facilities from the former site to the St. Lawrence River.

3. From information obtained from the Parish Priest, I learned that there are 112 boys and 145 girls who are 5 or 6 years of age and consequently will be of school age within a year or two. It would, therefore, appear that the school attendance for some time to come will remain at approximately the present figure of 350. After discussing the matter with the persons mentioned in the first part of this memorandum, I am of the opinion that the best provision to be made is as follows:
(a) Discard the Eastern School and construct a new school, with 10 classrooms and a basement, on the site of the former Senior School. In the basement of this building provision could be made for a kitchen and rooms for sewing and weaving. It would also provide sufficient accommodation for an assembly hall. This room need not be as elaborate as the assembly hall in the former Senior School, but Inspector Wescott and the Principal feel that for a school with an attendance of 350 some type of assembly hall is absolutely essential.

(b) Use the present Kateri School for vocational training for the boys. As previously stated, this is a four-roomed building in good condition and is situated within two or three minutes' walk of the site of the new school.

(c) If the suggestion made in "b" is adopted, provision should be made for teaching both wood-work and metal-work. This would require two male teachers. It may be interesting to you to have the following information regarding the boys who have graduated from the Caughnawaga R.C. School during the past six years:

| No. of Boys Graduated | Iron Workers | Armed Forces | Other Occupations | Dead |
|-----------------------|--------------|--------------|------------------|------|
| 1937                  | 7            | 4            | 2                | 1    |
| 1938                  | 10           | 4            | 3                | 2    |
| 1939                  | 7            | 3            | 4                |      |
| 1940                  | -            | -            | -                |      |
| 1941                  | 5            | 4            | 1                |      |
| 1942                  | 5            | 3            | -                | 2    |

The term "Iron Workers" in the above means those employed either with the Dominion Steel Company or the Dominion Bridge Company.

In discussing the educational requirements Mr. Brisebois expressed the opinion that the older boys should be under male teachers. I discussed this suggestion with Inspector Wescott, who stated that, while he agreed with the suggestion in principle, it would be impossible to carry it out in practice. If we engage Brothers for the older boys it will involve another residence and a great deal of extra arrangements. Mr. Wescott felt that the employment of two vocational training instructors at Caughnawaga, as suggested, would meet the situation adequately, as these two teachers would co-operate with the Sisters and would be able to discipline the older boys if necessary.
Referring back to paragraph "a", you will note I suggest discarding the Eastern School. This is a good building but is situated at a considerable distance from either the Kateri or the proposed new school. Both Inspector Wescott and Sister Mary George felt that it would be in the best interests of all parties concerned to concentrate our educational efforts closer together.

This would leave the Eastern School vacant. It is a good building, two stories high, with basement, and heated by a furnace. I feel that it would make a good office both for the Agent and the R.C.M. Police, or whatever other officials require to use it.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

First of all, we wish to thank you for arranging the matter of having the M.P. follow up truant cases. As previously agreed upon, we intend to use the M.P. only when every other means has failed.

We've been playing detective of late. Last Thursday night, someone broke into Kateri School again. We've followed a clue and this morning the police interviewed every boy concerned and we have the culprits—some of our own boys who have been playing truant since September. The M.P. are making their report and they suggested that we write you so that you might use a little pressure on the Attorney General's office so that a good lesson could be given these boys and serve as an example to the others. We do not mean to have them sent to reform school, but placed on a sort of a parole. They did not steal anything but broke flower pots and plants, disturbed things and did dirty things which we do not care to mention here. One good lesson at this time, will mean so much.

The desks have finally reached us and what a blessing they are. Thanks for these also.

Mr. Bush has kept very busy repairing radiators and doing all the repairs on the plumbing in our bathroom. He asks if he may be provided with a plumber's torch so that he may completely finish his work.

I beg to report that the back section of the steam furnace of the Kateri School at Caughnawaga gave out last Saturday, November 27, when it became impossible to heat the school. Mr. Garwood, plumber, of Chateauguay was called in and after having inspected the furnace stated that a new section was needed and that the repairs had to be made by the Gurney Foundry's men, the makers of same.

On Monday last, I called at the Gurney Foundry at the Town of St-Laurent where I was informed that they were no longer making any parts for the furnace that we have, a Gurney No.6, as it was too old and that their patterns were not usable. They stated that owing to the age of the furnace it was likely that another one will have to be installed as it has been in use for at least twenty five years.

On my return from St-Laurent, one Mr. Wilfrid Rice, who is in charge of the machinery at the local Golf Club and a very competent man in heating and pumping systems suggested that sealing compound be used to repair the furnace in order that it be used temporarily or pending such time as a new one is installed. This has been done and the school which had been closed for two days, on Monday and Tuesday of this week, has now reopened. However Mr. Rice has informed me that although the compound has stopped the leakages for the time being that the furnace itself is finished.

It would be advisable that an order be given to have a new furnace installed as soon as possible as if the sections do not hold, the school will have to be closed.

(Pre. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
December 3, 1943.

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent, Caughnawaga, Que.

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to the steam furnace in the Kateri School. I note that you will be unable to secure parts to permanently repair this furnace, but that you have succeeded in having temporary repairs made.

As you are aware, it is both difficult and costly to secure a new furnace at the present time and, if there is any possibility of keeping the present furnace going for the current winter, the Department feels that such action is most desirable.

However, if, after giving the matter further consideration, you feel that a new furnace must be secured in the near future, you should consult the Curney people, or any other firm from whom definite information can be secured, in order to ascertain what type of furnace we should order to ensure our obtaining the same service as from the present furnace and with the least possible change in piping. You understand, of course, that in supplying this information every possible detail should be given in order to assist our Purchasing Branch.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

SQUARE SECTIONAL HEATING BOILERS

For Hot Water or Steam

In this catalogue is presented the Gurney Line of Square Sectional Heating Boilers which consist of the 25, 30 and 40 Series Boilers. There is a size, in both Hot Water and Steam, to meet all practical requirements.

Gurney Square Sectional Boilers have always held a favored place with Canadian Heating Engineers and we feel certain that the Gurney Boilers will continue to hold this popularity. We know that they are efficient and are designed to meet the severe Canadian Heating conditions.

Accurate machining of nipple ports in the sections of all Gurney Square Boilers assure tight joints and ease of erection. Ninety-eight years of foundry experience assure the proper mixture of the correct grades of iron to produce castings of the greatest durability.

Introducing

THE NEW 25 SERIES BOILER

The Gurney Foundry Company, Limited, takes a great deal of satisfaction in announcing the introduction of the 25-SERIES BOILER to the present line of Gurney Boilers.

NEAT APPEARANCE

The attractiveness of the New 25-Series Boiler enables you to convert your cellar into a really useful place, such as a Recreation room, Play room, or any use according to your desire.

FINNED FOR EFFICIENCY

In the 25-Series Boiler, we introduce the latest feature in Cast Iron Boiler design, namely Finned Sections. These fins increase the efficiency of the boiler considerably as they add extra heating surface to the boiler. This means greater economy in fuels, particularly with Oil, Gas, Blower and Stoker Firing.

FUEL ECONOMY

The heating efficiency and economy of this new boiler is the direct result of nearly one hundred years of research and manufacture. To understand this statement, examine the interior of this new boiler. See the double-gallery FINNED FLUE giving a flue travel twice the boiler's length. Note the extensive array of water-filled vertical tubes in the path of the hot gases in both upper and lower flues which soak up all possible heat into the water and promote active circulation. Because these narrow, highly effective tubes form a greater heat absorbing area than the usual heating boiler can offer, the fuel burned by your heating system yields a definitely higher percentage of heat.
WATER TUBE DESIGN

The Gurney New Bright Idea is a water tube boiler built entirely of cast iron. The water tube design presents a large heating surface in proportion to the amount of water contained in the tubes. Quick response and economy of operation are features of a water tube boiler.

THREE CROWN HEATING SURFACES

A distinctive feature is the double gallery flue design which provides three separate and distinct crown heating surfaces...the most effective heating surface in any boiler. The fire travels to the back of the firebox, then to the front of the boiler through the first flue level and then back to the rear of the boiler through the upper gallery. The fire travel is the same in all sizes.

LARGE CLEANOUT DOORS

Large cleanout doors at the front of the boiler make it simple to clean all the flues. In addition there is a cleanout door at the back of the base through which the secondary combustion chamber may be cleaned.

ALL FUEL GRATES

The grates are so designed that even the small sizes of coal may be used. They are easy to operate for either shaking or dumping. The entire grate assembly on the 30 and 40 series boiler may be removed from the front of the boiler by first removing the front base panel.

EXCELLENT FOR OIL BURNING

Due to the all cast iron construction and the long fire travel, our 25, 30 and 40 series are excellent boilers for use with any oil burning equipment. They will give complete satisfaction with any type of fuel.

EASY TO ERECT

Ease of erection is an important feature of Gurney Boilers. This is due to the accurate machining of the sections and a simplified method of pulling them up. When installed, the clean, pleasing lines and the generous proportions give the boilers a smart, workmanlike appearance.

STEAM and HOT WATER HEATING
STEEL HEATING BOILERS

The new Gurney Steel Boiler has been specially designed for hot water or steam heating service. The characteristics have been determined after extensive research and many tests. The illustrations show the construction. The noteworthy features are:

The ample firebox and large combustion chamber assure exceptional combustion by thoroughly mixing the fuel bed gases with secondary air. This is accomplished with a minimum of excess air and results in remarkably high fuel efficiency.

The flow of gases after leaving the combustion chamber is of constant velocity through the boiler due to an improved arrangement of the tubes. This new tube distribution also insures an approximately equal volume of gas passing through each tube. Combined with the above, the long two-way fire travel guarantees maximum abstraction of heat.

The contour and size of the firebox permit long firing periods without sacrificing combustion efficiency. On special order, we will supply additional firebox depth for the maintenance of longer firing periods with low grade fuel.

The four water walls form a continuous column around the combustion chamber and firebox, with free circulation to the drum. This secures the benefit of complete absorption of radiant heat and prevents any restriction of water circulation. Due to the low water line and the resultant large steam releasing surface, remarkably dry steam is produced.

This boiler is manufactured of heavy plate and is welded by the latest improved equipment. All corners are fully rounded, eliminating troublesome right angle corner welds. The drum being a separate entity and entirely self supporting, the crown sheet does not require any stay bolts.

Hot water boilers are for safe operation at sixty pounds water pressure and can be supplied on special order for water pressure up to one hundred pounds. Steam boilers are designed for thirty pounds pressure and are approved for fifteen pounds operating pressure.

Standard shaking and dumping grates or stationary fine coal grates can be supplied. When ordered for oil burning, no grates are furnished.

Extended water legs for all Gurney Steel Stoker Fired Boilers comply with rulings recommended by stoker manufacturers.

Gross Ratings are in accordance with the "Code for the Rating of Low Pressure Heating Boilers" as adopted by the Steel Heating Boiler Institute.

Attention of Mr. Frs. Brisebois,

Gentlemen,

We are in receipt of your letter of December 16th requesting us to advise you as to the most suitable boiler to replace an old Gurney No. 946 Steam that is beyond repair. The most suitable boiler for this replacement would be our #40-5 Gurney square sectional steam heating boiler having a capacity of 2100 square feet of Equivalent Direct Radiation. This boiler has exactly the same capacity as the old No.946 and approximately the same physical dimensions. The price of this boiler complete is $754.00 list, f.o.b. Montreal, Federal Tax included, terms 2% 30 days, net 60 days. Delivery approximately six months after receipt of order.

We are unable at the present time to improve this delivery promise as we have quite a number of this type of boiler on order for the various Defence Forces which naturally carry a high priority. We can, however, supply you with a steel boiler of about the same capacity in approximately one month after receipt of order. This would be our No. 36-78.5S Gurney steel steam heating boiler having a net capacity of 215 square feet of Equivalent Direct Radiation. This boiler complete with base, grates, damper regulator, for hand firing, will cost $1016.00 list, f.o.b. Montreal, Federal Tax included, terms 2% 30 days net 60 days.

We are enclosing descriptive literature of both boilers.

Hoping this meets with your approval, we remain,

Yours very truly,

THE GURNEY MASSEY COMPANY, LIMITED.

R.A. Standring

NOTE:—The children attending the Caughnawaga R. C. School are accommodated in two buildings. One of these, known as the Kateri School, the present furnace has been in use for between 20 and 25 years. The back section of it cracked and temporary repairs were made. Recently, the front section of the furnace also cracked. A plumber who inspected it suggested that a new section was required, but when Indian Agent Brisebois visited the Gurney Foundry he was informed that they were no longer making any part for the furnace as old as the one we have at the present time. Mr. Doucet examined this furnace on Friday last and while it may be possible, by means of temporary repairs, to keep the furnace going for the balance of the current winter, there is a possibility that it may give out at any time. It would then be necessary to close the school, which accommodates approximately 140 children. Mr. Brisebois has obtained prices from the Gurney Foundry Company and I enclose their quotation for your information. Mr. Doucet recommends that the furnace requested in this requisition be supplied. His reasons for this are as follows:—(a) This type of furnace is welded instead of cast iron and consequently he feels it is a better purchase; (b) as previously stated, our present old furnace may give out at any time. It is therefore more important to have a new furnace installed at the earliest possible date. You will note that the one requested will be available within approximately one month. Attached is Gurney Foundry Company quotation to Mr. Brisebois, dated Dec. 29, 1943, also copy of their catalogue.

I hereby certify that I have personal knowledge that all the above articles are required in the Department and for departmental purposes only. The expenditure required by this requisition is strictly unavoidable and the public interest suffer if it is not made.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Kateri Indian School, Caughnawaga, Quebec.

The children attending the Caughnawaga Roman Catholic School are accommodated in two buildings and one of these is known as the Kateri School. The present furnace has been in use for between 20 and 25 years. Mr. Doucet visited this school last week and in his opinion the furnace should be replaced at the earliest possible date, as temporary repairs made to it from time to time are apt to prove insufficient. For your information I enclose a copy of a tender which we have received from the Gurney Foundry Company and Mr. Doucet favours the No. 36-72 AS Gurney Steel Steam Heating Boiler for two reasons: (a) This type of furnace is welded instead of cast iron and consequently he feels it is the better purchase; (b) As previously stated the present old furnace may give out at any time and it is, therefore, most important to have a new furnace installed as soon as possible.

We have submitted this request to the Purchasing Branch and they wish to obtain from your Branch advice as to whether or not the boiler specified is the most suitable size and type for the above school. To assist you in making a decision in this regard I enclose, for your information, a statement giving the measurements of this building.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

On January 17, 1944, a requisition was submitted to the Purchasing Agent for a Gurney steam heating boiler for the Caughnawaga R.C. Indian Day School. In a memorandum dated January 19 we were requested to obtain from the Surveys & Engineering Branch their advice as to whether or not the boiler specified in our requisition was the most suitable size and type.

The matter was submitted to the Surveys & Engineering Branch in our memorandum of January 20. As we received no reply we again wrote to them on February 5 and on February 17 we were advised as follows:

"In reply to your memoranda of January 20 and February 5, we are taking this matter up with several firms in Montreal and hope to be able to advise you further at an early date."

Since that time we have heard nothing further from the Surveys & Engineering Branch. Mr. Doucet visited the Caughnawaga School on Friday, February 11, and on that day the temperature of the classrooms was 45. The present boiler is in such condition that it is impossible to heat the building to a higher temperature and, as a result, some of the
children are allowed to go home and some stay at school, but are obliged to wear their coats. This is a condition that should not be allowed, as it not only interferes with the education of the pupils but also causes resentment on the part of both parents and children.

It would, therefore, be appreciated if you could arrange to have a new boiler ordered at the earliest possible date.

Director.

With further reference to my memorandum of February 17th last, and to previous correspondence relative to the above, the following is quoted for your information from a memorandum from Mr. Mills dated March 28th, and a copy of the quotation referred to therein is attached:

"Following receipt of your memorandum of February 17th last in connection with the above, this office communicated with the heating firms whose names you supplied viz:-

The Gurney Massey Co. Ltd.
P.O. Box 277, Montreal, Quebec.
E. Lefrancois,
5028 Chambord St., Montreal, Quebec.
Jos. A. Francoeur,
5312 Papineau St., Montreal, Quebec.

"Each firm was requested to inspect the existing installation, and forward a report with tender for supplying and installing a new boiler, together with any repairs or changes that would be required to adequately heat the building.

"No replies to our original request were received and on the 16th instant each firm was

(over)...........
"requested by wire to advise how soon the data could be expected here. In this connection the Gurney-Massey Co. replied that they were solely manufacturers of heating equipment, and were not in a position to furnish an estimate for the work. No reply to our wire was received from the other parties.

"On the 22nd instant, we again wired Messrs. Francoeur and Lefrancois, advising that unless we received their tenders without further delay, they would not be considered. As a result we are now in receipt of a detailed tender from E. Lefrancois, outlining work he is prepared to carry out for his tendered price of $1561.00.

"No tender has been received from Mr. Francoeur.

"While Mr. Lefrancois has not commented on the contents of his tender, he has submitted sketches of what is embodied. These may be summarized as follows:-

"The contractor has figured on retaining a one pipe system and on removing the existing Gurney Boiler, replacing it with an Ideal Boiler No. S36-7, manufactured by the Dominion Radiator Co. Ltd. This boiler is adequate for taking care of the existing connected radiators, together with 4 additional radiators which are considered necessary."
"The contractor has figured on adjusting the amount of radiation in each room, by moving several units from their existing positions and installing them in new locations to balance the room temperatures. He has included replacement of all air valves, as well as new radiators, new piping, pipe fittings and new smoke breeching to chimney. His tender including the above and all necessary labour amounts to $1561.00, subdivided under the following headings:

"Supplying No. 36-7 Ideal Steam Boiler and accessories.......................... $ 749.00
Sylphon Damper Regulator......................... 12.00
New piping, air vents, valves, pipe fittings, radiators and smoke breeching.. 345.00
Labour........................................... 450.00
Boiler inspection............................... 5.00

Total........ $1,561.00

"The contractor's sketches indicate that changes from the original layout, have been made in several of the classrooms. Partitions have been erected dividing the larger classrooms into two. This has resulted in unbalancing the radiation in the rooms effected, and is the reason for the contractor having included additional radiators in his tender.

"Upon analysis of the tender, and checking the items with the original Indian Affairs plans and the contractor's sketches, it is felt that the work covered is necessary, the equipment satisfactory and the price reasonable.

"You will recall that the price obtained by Indian Agent Brisebois from the Gurney-Massey Co. for a Gurney No. 40-6 steam boiler, which is similar in construction and capacity to the Ideal No. 36-7, was $754.00 F.O.B. Montreal.

(over).............
"The contractor was not asked to give dates for beginning or completing operations, but some delay in delivery of a boiler might reasonably be expected under present conditions."

Mr. Mills' opinion that the equipment etc. proposed by Mr. E. Lefrancois will take care of the situation in a satisfactory manner, and that his tender should be accepted, is concurred in.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Heating System, Kateri Indian Day School, Caughnawaga, Quebec.

I have your memorandum of March 30, in connection with the above and have carefully noted its contents. I note that the quotation received by you includes some changes to the radiators etc. in addition to installing the new boiler. However, the boiler mentioned in the quotation from Mr. Lefrancois is not the same boiler as recommended in our memorandum of January 20 last. Besides, there is an item of $450 for labour. Our officials feel that this is an excessive amount for the work required.

Although the teachers and children have suffered considerable inconvenience, due to the fact that we did not replace the boiler earlier, at the same time the present heating season is nearly past and there is no great urgency for installing a new boiler within the next few weeks. We must, however, have the new boiler installed before October 1, 1944, in order to ensure adequate heating for the winter of 1944-45.

In view of the above I feel that the matter can be delayed for a time and it would be appreciated if you would have one of your officers visit the Kateri
School and make certain that the quotation of Mr. Lefrancois is reasonable. We would also like to draw your attention to the fact mentioned above; namely, that we suggested a different type of boiler from that quoted by Mr. Lefrancois.

Director.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

This is a personal plea. As you are aware, our motor on our oil furnace in the teachers' residence burnt out on March 19th. Since that time, we have been using wood to heat up the house but with poor results. Yesterday and today have been miserable days, the temperature in the residence being between 54 and 58.

Mr. Bush is doing all he can but we cannot ask him to be on the job twenty four hours a day and therefore a sister fills up the furnace every hour or so. Couldn't you possibly do something to help us out? We assure you that we would appreciate heat since all this year has been a year of suffering from lack of heat either at school or at home. I feel that the sisters' health is suffering from this, for nearly all of them are having colds, sore throats, she came down with double-pneumonia. Please come to our rescue.

Thanking you for your kind attention to this matter, we beg to remain

Very respectfully yours,

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent, Caughnawaga, Que.

With reference to requisition for supplies for the schools and teachers' residences on the Caughnawaga Reserve, you may purchase 3 ordinary alarm clocks and 6 waste paper baskets.

R.A.Hoey, Esq., Supt., of Welfare and Education, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

I have your letter of the 19th ultimo dealing with a requisition for the Schools and Teacher's Residence and in this connection to advise that the alarm clocks and the waste paper baskets have been ordered from Mr. Lanctot, Merchant, St-Isidore, Que.

In connection with the caulking compound (10 gallons) and one caulking gun I wish to inform that the prices are as follows; compound $1.38 per gallon less 20% (in one gallon containers) caulking gun $7.44.

The above would be needed to put around the windows and the doors of the local Schools in order to prevent the cold from getting in. It is believed that the cost of this material would soon be reimbursed by the economy of fuel which would result. The work to be done free of charge by the Janitor.

Caughnawaga, August 5, 1944.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Herewith enclosed, you will find the picture of the Caughnawaga R. C. Indian Day School graduates for 1944. As you will readily see, we had a nice group of graduates this year. These boys and girls are certainly about the best pupils who have left the Caughnawaga school. We hope they will continue to be a credit to the Department. Most of them are planning to continue their schooling in the fall.

We wish to take this opportunity to thank you and all the other members of the Department who have been instrumental in obtaining a new unit for our frigidaire. The long-coveted prize has at last arrived and has alleviated conditions very much.

The furnace in Kateri School has also been installed. For this also, we are very grateful.

We are now trying to plan where to place all our pupils in September. The schools were overflowing last year—seven graduates left and some sixty new pupils are expected for the first grade. We could use a magic wand and create a few extra rooms.

We are still looking forward to your long-promised visit.

Respectfully yours,

Sisters of Saint Ann

Dear Sister Mary George:

Please accept my sincere thanks for your letter of August 5 and for the photograph sent forward therewith.

It was kind and thoughtful of you to send forward this information. I can only express the hope that provision will be made in the immediate, post-war programme for the erection of a fully equipped Indian day school on the Caughnawaga Reserve. We are keeping in mind also the fact that a residence for the teachers is urgently needed.

It is my hope that I may be able to visit you early in the coming academic year.

Again thanking you for your letter, I remain,

Yours sincerely,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

I am sending forward herewith a report submitted by Mr. Phelan, immediately following a survey undertaken by him, Mr. Doucet and Mr. Buck of the schools and agency buildings at the Caughnawaga Reserve, Que.

May I direct your attention particularly to Mr. Phelan's suggestion that the school on the reserve, now known as the Eastern School, be remodelled and used as an Indian agency office and Indian council chamber and that a 12-room school be built on the site of the senior school destroyed by fire.

I have discussed these matters very fully with Mr. Phelan and with Mr. Doucet, and I am disposed to think that the recommendations made are in conformity with the actual needs of the Indian population on the reserve. MEMORANDUM:

MR. HOEY

Re: Education Requirements at Caughnawaga.

I wish to submit this report as a supplement to Mr. Phelan's report dated November 6th, dealing with the building requirements on the Caughnawaga Reserve.

I had the pleasure of meeting F.J. McHugh of the Dominion Bridge Company, Personnel Manager and William Bell, Construction Engineer. I also interviewed Mr. J. Conrath, Works Manager of the Dominion Plant of the Canadian Car and Foundry.

My point of interest was to find out what these gentlemen considered necessary or advantageous in the training of young Indians who might be employed by them. They all agreed that the teaching of geometry and the reading of plans along with general mathematics would give these young people a greater opportunity. As far as skills were concerned they mentioned welding, electrical and gas, and metal firing. It is hardly possible for us, because of the young age of the children on leaving school to give training in these skills. Pupils, however, could be picked out who have aptitude in this line and encouraged to carry their training beyond the age of sixteen.

I might say that, the day is fast approaching when the Department as an educational agency for Indians, will have to formulate its own programme of study in co-ordination with the various provinces.

The above needs have been kept in mind when the building programme as contained in the above mentioned report was recommended.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR
Surveys & Engineering Branch
Re: Caughnawaga R.C. School

It is our intention to include in the first year of the post-war building programme a new school on the Caughnawaga Reserve. Mr. Buck is familiar with conditions on this reserve, as Mr. Phelan and Mr. Doucet discussed the proposed building with him while at Caughnawaga on November 3 last. Before proceeding with the plans I should appreciate it if you would arrange to have Mr. Buck telephone Mr. Doucet so that the latter may discuss with Mr. Buck some of our requirements.

Broadly speaking we would like to have a building with twelve classrooms, also rooms in the basement for kitchen, sewing room, weaving room and playroom.

Toilet facilities should also be provided in the basement.

We suggest steam heating and electric lighting, also the installation of a simple ventilation system.
At the present time we do not favour placing the heating system in the basement, but in a separate addition, and I believe it would be advisable to provide for a stoker, in order that reasonably priced coal may be used.

Acting Director.

Memorandum:

In connection with my recent visit to Caughnawaga, I believe that certain faulty procedures in the operation of the furnaces of the schools, should be noted. The correction of the above should, I believe, increase the efficiency of the heating system.

I am fully aware that it is impossible to obtain a trained fireman. I would not be prepared to say that a change would bring about any improvement. However, I believe that certain facts should be brought to the attention of the Indian Agent who should be instructed to have our instructions carried out:

1. The flues of the steam furnaces should be cleaned weekly. This should be systematically done every Saturday.
2. The method of checking the furnace by leaving the fuel door open cannot be justified. This door should be open only when adding coal to the fire. Instructions were given to the Janitor on several occasions, once you will recall in your presence but these instructions are not carried out.
3. When feeding coal into the furnace, the rear damper should be closed while the furnace damper should be open. After closing the fuel door the furnace damper should be at least partially closed and when the furnace is burning freely completely closed.
4. In order to check the furnace the rear damper should be open more or less as conditions require.
I noticed that the recently installed furnace was equipped with automatic damper controls. These however have been removed. The Janitor claims that they were not functioning but I am rather inclined to believe that he does not understand this apparatus.

Generally, the companies furnish instructions on the operation of their furnaces. These should be posted near the furnace and carefully followed. The Agent should be instructed to obtain a copy of these instructions and have it posted in a conspicuous place near the furnace.

I wish to draw your attention to the above having in mind the difficulties that have been encountered in heating the Caughnawaga schools.

Respectfully submitted,

A.J. Doucet.

Ottawa, January 3, 1945.
Ottawa, January 4, 1945.

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, Que.

Mr. Doucet has reported regarding his recent visit to Caughnawaga, especially with respect to the new furnace in the Kateri School. He is not satisfied with the manner in which the furnace is being operated. I therefore suggest that the following instructions be given to the janitor and that you make arrangements to see that these instructions are put into effect:

1. The flues of the steam furnaces should be cleaned weekly. This should be systematically done every Saturday.

2. The method of checking the furnace by leaving the fuel door open cannot be justified. This door should be open only when adding coal to the fire. Instructions were given to the Janitor on several occasions, once you will recall in your presence, but these instructions are not carried out.

3. When feeding coal into the furnace, the rear damper should be closed while the furnace damper should be open. After closing the fuel door, the furnace damper should be at least partially closed and when the furnace is burning freely, completely closed.

4. In order to check the furnace, the rear damper should be open more or less, as conditions require.

Mr. Doucet also noticed that the automatic damper controls had been removed from the furnace. This
should not have been done, and damper controls should be again installed.

It is the usual practice for a company to furnish instructions on the operation of their furnaces. If they neglected to do so, I would appreciate it if you would secure a copy of these instructions immediately, discuss them with the janitor and post the instructions in a conspicuous place near the furnace.

It has occurred to me that in view of your many duties it may not be possible for you to visit the Kateri School sufficiently often to ascertain if the janitor is operating the furnace in a proper manner. Might I suggest that when you find it impossible to visit the school you send Mr. LaPlante. It would not require very much time, and he could report to you if the janitor is following instructions and, if not, you could then interview the janitor and point out to him the mistakes that he is making.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, January 4, 1945.

Dear Mr. Brisebois:

With reference to my letter of the 4th instant, regarding the furnace at the Kateri School, paragraph numbered 1 read as follows:

"The flues of the steam furnaces should be closed weekly. This should be systematically done every Saturday."

This should have read:

"The flues of the steam furnaces should be cleaned weekly. This should be systematically done every Saturday."

Please make the necessary correction in the letter of January 4.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
