Dear Mr. Doucet:

This letter is to ask you if the Department would approve the purchase of enough lumber so that the boys of Eastern School may build a fence in front of their schools.

The boys have offered to do the work under Mr. Wescott's supervision. Mr. Wescott finds it a very sound and practical idea. All this would be done in an effort to keep the playgrounds clean—otherwise, roaming animals use the yard as pasture land.

The approximate linear measure of this fence would be 215 ft. The pickets could be made up by the boys and given a wide space. Would you kindly tell us what you think of this project?

Philip Phelan, Esq., Chief, Training Division, Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

I have your letter of the 23rd of March last dealing with the installation of a new pump at the local Eastern School, and in this connection to say that when the old pump was removed for examination to determine the repairs needed it was found out that the repairs were to cost as much as the price of a new pump and moreover it was stated that if repairable there was no guarantee that it could be repaired before two or three months. The old pump was of American make and had been in use for over 22 years.

In view of the fact that water was much needed at the school in view of the steam heating system etc., and that no savings would have been effected by repairing same it was thought advisable to have a new one installed.

I regret the delay in answering your letter as it had been mislaid at this office.

[Fra. Brisebois]

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT.

I attach account amounting to $89.30 covering the cost of a new pump and fixtures required at the Caughnawaga R. C. School. The pump was needed immediately, due to the fact that it supplied the water for the steam heating plant. The Agent therefore made arrangements for the immediate installation of a new pump. The pump was needed immediately, due to the fact that it supplied the water for the steam heating plant. The Agent therefore made arrangements for the immediate installation of a new pump. It would be appreciated if you would issue purchase order so that the account may be paid. The coding is as follows: - 305-76-12-422.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Encl.
Caughnawaga, May 25th, 1945.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Can.

I wish to refer to your letter of the 23 ultimo dealing with the proposed erection of a wooden fence in front of the Eastern School, and to say that Mr. Wescott will soon give us the particulars needed for an estimate.

I wish to report however that the fence adjoining lots Nos. 461, 462, 457 and 459, that is the sides and the back of the school lot, is now in dilapidated condition and needs to be renewed at the earliest possible date as the four Indian owners of the above mentioned lots will not be able to make any garden. Without a new fence the pupils are all over their properties and also the cattles which are still allowed to roam about.

For the sides and the back of the lot a 5 ft. wire fence of ordinary make is suggested. This fence wire is priced at .10¢ a foot. Wooden posts are not obtainable and steel posts of 8 ft. long would be required.

In addition to ordinary posts, two steel corner posts would be needed and also two end posts. This fence would have a total length of 600 ft., and the price of the wire would be of .10¢ per foot. Fifty six ordinary posts (steel) would be required at a cost of .59¢ each. The two corner posts are priced at $12.20 and the two end posts $9.95 each. In addition about a ton of crushed stone at $1.50, between six or eight bags of cement at .60¢ would be needed. The labor could be made by our janitor with the help of one man. The labor to cost around $20.

These prices were obtained from the Frost Steel & Wire Co., through their local agent, Louis A. Dailleboust, who recently started a hardware store on this Reserve.

An early reply to this letter would be much appreciated.

Indian Agent.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I have your letter of the 16th instant informing that at a recent visit at Ottawa, Chief Councillor Lazare, has remitted you a letter from one Mrs. Joseph Delisle in which she claimed $85.00 for damage suffered to her buildings and garden due to lack of proper fencing at the Eastern School.

In reply I wish to say that this fence was completed at the beginning of this month. The old fence was practically non-existent having been torn down by the pupils and other children, including her own.

When the men were erecting the fence this woman, who had complained that cattle and horses were coming on her lot through the school yard, was told that she could still make a garden if she had her ploughing done immediately, neglected to do so having apparently made up her mind not to cultivate this year.

This family owns Lot No. 462 which is located directly at the back of the School yard. This lot is of a total area of about one half an acre, not one acre as stated on her letter.

It may be that a little damage was suffered from the bad state of the fence but her claim, in my opinion, is greatly exaggerated.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I have your letter of the 25th instant dealing with the purchase of an oil heater for the new classroom located at Mrs. J. Jacobs and in reply to say that the oil burner mentioned in my letter of the 20th could be obtained at Dupuis Freres Ltd., St-Catherine st., east, Montreal. This burner was of the ordinary type (large) with an air circulator attached. Price $120.00.

Having further inquired I wish to advise that the Raymond Hardware Ltd., 658 Craig st., west, Montreal, could supply us with a Royal Class Standard Oil burner, without a circulator attachment, for the price of $65.00. This heater will be sufficient to heat this classroom, which is 32 feet long, 19 wide and 9½ high, which represents the cubic space of an average six rooms dwelling house.

The Raymond Hardware would be in a position to deliver this stove in about 15 days after the receipt of the order.

The delivery at Dupuis Freres could not be guaranteed in that length of time, but they would likely consented to ship us the one they had as a sample in their showroom.

It would be appreciated if the purchase of the stove could be made as soon as possible.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

Re: Senior School,
Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Quebec.

A memorandum from the Acting Director of Indian Affairs, dated December 12, 1944, gave a general outline of what would be required for a building to replace the Senior School at the above Agency, which was destroyed by fire in December 1941, and on the basis of that information, preliminary sketch drawings have been prepared, and three sets of black line prints of these, are attached for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch for their study.

These rough sketches show the suggested twelve classrooms, and make provision for sewing, cooking, and handicraft activities for the girls, as well as manual training for the boys, on the lower floor. Two other floors provide accommodation for a maximum of 480 pupils in six classrooms of 40 pupils each.

The building is intended to be completely fireproof with a reinforced concrete frame, and outer walls of hollow tile faced with brick and trimmed with cut stone. This trim, however, has been kept to the minimum. The building would be steam heated from a central heating plant which would also supply heat to a teachers' residence which will eventually be built close to the school. A simple ventilation system would be provided.

It would be necessary to drill a well for a water supply, but electricity is available.

Some years ago, at considerable expense to the then, Indian Affairs Department, a sewer line was built to discharge sewage directly into the Saint Lawrence River. Owing to the very rocky nature and limited area of the site, no additional sewage disposal facilities have been anticipated. It is felt that branch lines to the existing sewer would permit the use of this installation.

The building, as shown in the sketches, is estimated to cost in the vicinity of $115,000.00.

We have not forwarded prints for your files, since drawings are available in our Architectural Division, at any time you should require them.

Enclos.

Chief Engineer.

To whom it may concern,

I have written twice before and I also have been to the Indian agents every week on this same matter, concerning the loss of my garden which is connected with the Boys Eastern school. I claim a loss of eighty-five dollars in which I have to cover two shed roofs and plants have been trampled down by animals.

I would greatly appreciate your kindness if you can arrange this as soon as possible as I depended my living for the winter months on my garden.

Mr. Brilais has been telling me for the last six months that the money may come in any day, I would like an immediate reply!
Should you forward any reply it will be on my address.

Mr. Joseph Delisle
Caughinawage,
Box 16
Ottawa, January 26, 1946.

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent, Caughnawaga, Quebec.

Two members of the Caughnawaga Band visited the Department this morning and left with me the following letter written by Mrs Joseph Delisle, Box 16, Caughnawaga, Quebec:

"I have written twice before and I also have been to the Indian Agent's every week on the same matter, concerning the loss of my garden which is connected with the Boy's Eastern School. I claim a loss of eighty-five dollars, in which I have to cover two shed roofs and plants have been trampled down by animals.

I would greatly appreciate your kindness if you can arrange this as soon as possible as I depended my living for the winter months on my garden.

Mr. Brisebois has been telling me for the last six months that the money may come in any day. I would like an immediate reply".

In connection with the above, I would refer you to my letter of July 6th, 1945 and your reply of July 20th, 1945.

At the time we received your communication it was discussed with the Director. In the second paragraph of your letter you state that the old fence was practically non-existent having been torn down by the pupils and other children, including her own. It would, therefore, appear that the mere fact that there was some delay in building the new fence would not cause her any extra injury."
One of her claims was that the old fence was torn down some time before the date on which the new fence was erected and it was during this time that the damage occurred.

In the third paragraph of your letter you stated that if Mrs. Delisle was anxious to cultivate a garden during 1945 she could have done so prior to the erection of the new fence.

We can not see that she has a just claim and consequently you should advise her that we are not prepared to make any payment to her.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

This is the tale of the unseen elements that lurk in most natural waters. Like the evil spirits of legend, they cause havoc wherever they go, injuring hair, skin, clothing; wasting soap and fuel, and adding hours of needless drudgery to household tasks.

For a better understanding of these invisible enemies consider the wanderings of water from the clouds to your house. In its purest state, falling as rain or snow, water contains some gases and dissolved dust. Then it soaks into soil, sweeps over rock strata, and finally bubbles to the surface in springs which feed rivers and lakes. Water, being the universal solvent, dissolves at least part of everything it touches. This explains the presence in most untreated waters of these troublemakers, lime, magnesia, and other minerals—the hardening elements normally indistinguishable by sight or taste.

When soap and water meet, the indisputable test of water hardness occurs right before your eyes. Soft water flows immediately into plentiful, rich, foamy suds, which cleanse thoroughly and wash away easily. In hard water, before any cleansing action can be accomplished, part of the soap must be wasted in neutralizing the water’s mineral salts. The result—a sticky film of insoluble soap curd and very skimpy lather. This soap scum adheres to everything it touches and requires laborious rubbing and scrubbing for only partial removal.

Dishes washed in soft water suds, with much less soap, dry to a clear sparkle without toweling. Silver retains its satiny gleam, glassware shines. You save soap, time and work.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Pursuant to our conversation of August 3rd during which you have kindly granted the need of an electric stove for our residence, we have gone to the General Electric Co., Limited, to price them. We are including a sample of the kind and size we wish to have with the price as given us at the office by Mr. McGarrity. We would deeply appreciate your attention to this request.

We wish to provide 5th grade of Eastern School with individual desks, medium size. It will facilitate the difficult work which we foresee our teacher will have with these 5th graders. Would the Department kindly order three dozen of these desks, of which order one dozen would complete the number of individual desks required to outfit 6th grade, boys and girls, in Kateri School?

Mr. Douwet allowed Sr. Superior to obtain Algebras for the upper grades; however the order was not put in then as the school year was already quite advanced. We believe Sr. Superior planned ordering them for the coming year. May we put in the order now from "Montreal Book Room, Ltd., 1455 McGill, 44 Algebras and 44 Histories entitled "Europe in the Modern World"? Would you wish us to call for these two kinds of books separately so that the bill will not exceed $100?

I have visited the schools last week, and I cannot refrain from saying how painfully surprised I am at the conditions in which our teachers and pupils must work. I know you are aware of the situation and no doubt with every teacher here you are eager to see the walls of a new school and residence rise. A newspaper heading a few days ago made our hopes soar high.... Ottawa is to take measures for the building of 80,000 houses in 1947.... A spontaneous cry dropped from all our teachers' lips: "Are our new school and residence comprised in this resolution?"
I wish to thank you, dear Mr. Phelan, for the courtesy and kindness shown Sr. M. George and myself during our visit to you and wish to assure you of my earnest wish to serve the interests of the Department in favor of our Indians.

Respectfully yours,

SISTERS OF ST. ANN.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Ottawa.

Sr. Mary Albertus S.S.A.

Caughnawaga, November 8th, 1946.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Can.

I beg to transmit you herewith voucher No. 597, in the amount of $439.25, in favour of Mr. L.E. Beauvais, Electrical Contractor, Caughnawaga, Que., for labour employed by him for the cleaning of the sewer pipe line from the Caughnawaga R.C. Kateri School to its outlet in the St. Lawrence River.

This work was undertaken as an emergency in the course of September at the opening of the school term for 1946-47, as the toilet in that school could not be used on account of the sewer pipe being blocked by dirt, roots, etc., and also a few broken lengths of pipes, and that it was feared by the writer that it might be a cause of infection during that severe period of the poliomyelitis epidemic.

I would therefore kindly ask you to have this account passed for payment at your early convenience.

With reference to the above, I wish to report that on the 2nd inst., a complaint was received from the Superior of the Catholic School, Caughnawaga, Que., to the effect that seven 24 x 28" windows of the girl's school have been broken during the evening of October 31st 1946 which was Halloween night.

An examination of the school revealed that seven window panes measuring 24 x 28" were broken on both the East and North sides. Due to the size of the holes in these broken windows there is no doubt that this damage was caused by stones.

It is estimated that on the evening of the 31st ult., about three-hundred young children of the Caughnawaga Indian Reserve were masqueraded and were playing between this school and Kirby's dance hall where a dance was taking place.

During the course of an investigation in this matter it was learned that the above named has been boasting about breaking a window at the Girl's school on this particular evening.

Consequently, on the 5th inst., Angeline DIABO was interviewed and questioned in this connection and she vehemently denied having anything to do with the damage caused at the school. She however admitted having thrown a stone which struck the porch of the school but assured us that she never broke any window.

Further investigation in this case revealed that Angeline DIABO was seen with Lorraine CANOE on the evening of the 31st ult. The latter party was therefore questioned and from her statement obtained it is disclosed that Angeline DIABO did break a school window on this evening. Hereunder is a statement obtained from Lorraine CANOE:

Caughnawaga, Que.,
Nov., 12th 1946.

I, Lorraine CANOE, age 13 years, daughter of Mrs. Marian CANOE, residing at Caughnawaga, Que., wish to make the following statement, willingly and knowing it to contain the whole truth.

At approximately 9.30 p.m. on October 31st 1946, I was with Edith Canadian, Russel Canadian and Angeline DIABO. We began to play near the Girl's school of Caughnawaga, Que., while we were waiting

(P.T.C.)
for our friends to join us to attend the Halloween dance which was taking place at the Kirby's dance Hall.

While playing with my friends mentioned above, I saw Angeline DIABO pick up a stone and walk near the school and throw it a stone in the direction of the school. Angeline DIABO broke the window on the east side of the school, but I cannot say if she did it intentionally or accidentally. I do not know if Russel and Edith CANADIAN saw Angeline DIABO break the window, but I sincerely believe they did see her.

After this, we all went to my home where we remained for a few minutes only. We then returned to the dance hall. Edith Canadian and Angeline were walking together in front of us, and myself, accompanied by Russel Canadian, Stewart Mylow and Roland Perron, were following them by a short distance. The two last persons were walking behind us. As Russel Canadian and I had passed the school, we heard two windows break and I am of the opinion that these windows were broken by Stewart Mylow and Roland Perron. We all met at the dance hall and there was not a word mentioned about the broken windows.

This is all I know in this case.

(SGD) Lorraine CANOE.

7. After obtaining this statement, Angeline DIABO was again interviewed on this date and a sworn statement was obtained from her. It will be noted from her own statement that she admits having broken one window of the school. After being given the legal warning, the following statement was obtained and sworn to by L.E. Beausais, J.P.:-

Caughnawaga, Que.,
November 11th 1946.

I, Angeline DIABO, 17 years old, daughter of Matthew DIABO, residing at Caughnawaga, Que., wish to make the following statement, willingly and knowing it to contain the whole truth after having been duly warned.

At approximately 9.30 p.m. on October 31st 1946, I was with Lorraine CANOE, Edith CANADIAN and Russel CANADIAN. We began to play near the Girl's school.
while we were waiting for our friends to join us to attend the Halloween dance which was taking place at the Kirby's dance hall.

Whilst playing with my friends mentioned above, I picked up a stone and threw it at the Girl's school and accidentally broke a 24 x 26" window on the east side of the school. I cannot say if Lorraine CANOE Edith and Russel CANADIAN did break any windows as we were all throwing stones in all directions. However, these three friends of mine saw me break the window of the school.

After this we proceeded to Lorraine CANOE's home where we remained for a few minutes only. Edith CANADIAN and I proceeded direct to the dance hall whilst Lorraine CANOE and her friends were following us by a short distance. When the latter party passed by the school I could hear some stones being thrown and I also heard one or two windows break. With the exception of Lorraine CANOE, I cannot say who were the members of the gang following us and who broke the other windows. Edith CANADIAN and I proceeded to the dance hall, where we remained together till the end of the dance which finished at about 1.00 a.m.

This is all I have to say in this case.

(SGD) Angeline DIABO.

MEMORANDUM:

Re: New Senior Day School, Boiler House and Future Teachers' Residence,
Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Quebec.

In the development of plans and specifications for the above, and with provision being made for the Teachers' Residence, the question of adequate fire protection has been kept in mind; and we submit for the consideration of Indian Affairs Branch, at this time, our recommendation in this connection.

Since there is no existing system of water mains or modern fire fighting equipment at Caughnawaga, we believe that a complete system including a fire pump, underground mains, fire hydrants, and stand pipes within the buildings, together with such necessary items as hose, racks, etc., should be provided. The fire pump would be located in the Boiler House and would pump water from the St. Lawrence River, delivering it to the hydrants at a pressure of 100 pounds per square inch. The supply main would be laid below frost, adjoining the School trunk sewer line, in the excavation prepared in 1933 when the sewer was installed.

We have made a rough estimate of the cost of such an installation, and using equipment which meets the Fire Underwriters' requirements, we believe that this work could be carried out for approximately $15,000, which would include contingencies and supervision.

We will await instructions before proceeding with a layout, and should approval be given, it is felt that the outside work should be carried out under a separate contract.

Chief Engineer.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,

Dear Mr. Doucet:

We have just received notice of the purchase of an electric stove for our residence. We believe it is thanks to a kind "hint" you must have given to the members of the Department. However we are grateful to the person responsible for this step.

No doubt you have been very busy since your visit to Gaughnawaga. We were hoping to hear from you concerning the purchase of a combined faucet for our kitchen sink, and for a small electric stove "hot point". May I take the liberty, Sir, of recalling the other subjects treated during your visit and inquire whether any decision has been taken by the Department concerning these?

a) a water softener

b) some lumber or ten test for the separation we wish to make in our entrance.

c) an oil cloth for our kitchen; here are the measures taken by Mr. Bush: 16 by 22

d) the black felt paper and sheets of ten test for the covering of the floor of the second grade classroom located in Mrs. Jacobs' store is not needed now since Mr. Bush has changed the small furnace for the bigger one which was at the Bush School.

We have visited the classrooms quite often. The pupils seem to be very much interested in their school work and, in general, are attending school quite regularly. We have also
visited St. Isidore Road School every month. The teacher, Miss Bush, is doing fine work with the grades. We are much interested in the Nutrition contest launched by Dr. Moore. It should prove of great benefit to our Indian pupils.

With renewal thanks for past kindness and kind greetings to the members of the Department, we remain, kind Sir,

Yours sincerely,

Sr. Mary Albertine S.S.A.
Principal

Mr. A.J. Doucet,
Training Division,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, December 18, 1946.

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent, Caughnawaga, P.Q.

In a letter of the 9th instant, the Principal of the Caughnawaga School refers to a temporary partition in the side entrance to their residence and a combination faucet for the kitchen sink. I believe that I discussed this with you during my last visit, however, I may be wrong about this. The point is that the Principal was to endeavour to obtain a kitchen faucet at an approximate cost of $10.00 and submit the voucher to this office for payment.

As regards the partition, I suggested that she obtain the necessary material and have the boys under the direction of Mr. Wescott construct this movable partition. Kindly let me have your opinion in this matter.

What has happened to the two sinks that were to be installed in the bathroom and teacher's residence?

What happened to my auto-knitter?

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor, Training Division.
Ottawa, December 18, 1946.

Rev. Sister M. Albertus, Principal, Caughnawaga Indian Day School, Caughnawaga, P.Q.

In reply to your letter of December 9th, I had taken no action as far as the oilcloth for the kitchen is concerned as you will recall I had asked Mr. Bush to give me an accurate estimate of the amount required. This letter gives me the measurements as sixteen feet by twenty-two feet. I presume that this ignores the well "that is the opening for stairway". I will ascertain whether or not this linoleum can be purchased and I will let you know in the near future.

With regard to the ten test for a separation I was under the impression that we decided to make a kind of a movable partition at this spot and that Mr. Wescott was going to undertake this with a few of the boys. I believe, that I authorized the Agent to purchase the material and submit the vouchers to us for payment.

The "A" part of your letter - the water softener -. We have never received an analysis of the water. This is necessary before we can take any steps towards the purchase of this softener.

I have been away on an extensive trip out West and have been unable to check the files to verify what has been done.
I wish to thank you for the St. Catherine's parcels that you sent for the children. They certainly appreciated the candy.

Yours for better Indian education,

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor, Training Division.
Att. Mr. Doucet.

I have your letter of the 18th instant dealing with a letter received from the Sister Superior of Gaughnawaga dealing with a temporary partition at the side entrance of their residence and a combination faucet for the kitchen sink.

These have been ordered at Raymond Hardware over two months ago, but have not been delivered yet. We do not wish to buy same at prices exceeding the ceiling.

Your suggestion that the side partition be built by the boys under the supervision of Mr. Westcott should be acceptable. The only objection is that the weather might be too cold for the boys at this time of the year.

The auto-knitter was shipped directly from Montreal to the St-Phillips Residential School, Saskatchewan, a long time ago.

Memorandum

Re: Electrical Design for New Senior Day School
New Senior Day School,
Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Quebec.

For your information you are informed that discussions were held January 24th last between Mr. Neary and Mr. Clark of the Indian Affairs Branch and Mr. Kosnar of this Service in connection with the electrical design of the above building.

The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the various types of equipment proposed for use in the school, requiring electrical connections, in order that proper provisions may be made in the design, in respect to location and capacity, as all wiring will be concealed during erection in the reinforced concrete and hollow tile construction.

Following is a list of special subjects that were discussed at length and decisions arrived at are noted.

1. Lighting

It was felt that a good system of lighting should be installed in keeping with modern day practice with special attention being given to the classrooms weaving and sewing rooms, where the visual tasks involved are greater than elsewhere. The general classroom lighting was discussed fully and it was decided that this Service would prepare a cost analysis comparison between fluorescent and incandescent lighting systems for consideration before laying out the lighting in these areas. It was agreed that special blackboard lighting units should be installed in the classrooms in addition to the general lighting system.

2. Signal System

After discussing this matter it was decided that an automatic electrical signal system operating bells on each floor, and on the exterior wall of the school for the playground area, would provide adequate control for class movements. All bells in this system will be controlled from a clock located in the office which would be set to operate the bell system automatically in any time sequence desired.

3. Electrical Equipment

Electrical outlets for connections to apparatus such as electric ranges and other heating or motor loads necessary in the kitchen, weaving and sewing rooms was considered and it was agreed that this Service would supply the Indian Affairs Branch with a plan of these areas for the purpose of making an equipment layout for incorporation in our working drawings. We understand the Welfare and Training Division of Indian Affairs are concentrating attention on this matter at the moment.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director, Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

4. Telephones

Telephone requirements were left in abeyance pending return to Ottawa of the officer of the Indian Affairs Branch, charged with this responsibility, at which times further consideration would be given this item.

5. Clocks

It was felt that clocks located elsewhere than in the office would be unwarranted in view of the automatic signal system to be provided.

6. Fire Alarm System

It was decided that an electric fire alarm system with two stations on each floor operating bells located in hallways was desirable. The suggestion was made that a mechanical system be installed as well but decision on this is pending further investigation.

7. Plug Receptacles

This subject was dealt with in general and particularly in classrooms where special equipment is likely to be used.

Any special items other than those mentioned in the above, that are foreseen by Indian Affairs in connection with apparatus for the school, should be brought to the attention of this Service at their earliest possible convenience.

Re: New Senior Day School, Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Quebec.

On the 8th instant, this office received three memoranda from the Indian Affairs Branch as follows:

Memo. (a) Dated February 21st signed by Mr. B.F. Neary, regarding wall receptacles to service visual education appliances, and requesting slanting black-boards.

Memo. (c) Dated March 5th, over Mr. Neary's signature expressing the understanding of Indian Affairs that tenders would be called not later than March 16th next.

Each memorandum carried your notation dated March 7th, 1947.

Dealing with this correspondence in the order referred to above you are advised as follows:

Memo. (a) Provision has been made in our electrical design for the wall receptacles, (wall plugs); but no slanting black-boards have been designed. We have made provision for black-boards to be efficiently illuminated by fluorescent black-board lighting fixtures.

It was felt then that if two Indian properties on the highway, (between which a right of way 47'10" wide, gives access to Crown lands) could be purchased, the new group of buildings could be planned to occupy land a fair distance north of the site of the destroyed school.

At that time the Indian Affairs Officers stated that it would be difficult if not impossible to obtain possession of the Indian properties and our architectural work was begun on the basis of restoration ourselves to the property, we knew was Crown Lands.

Under date of November 2nd 1945, copies of our drawing P1, Index 811 were forwarded to Indian Affairs, showing a building arrangement that we considered attractive, and economical to operate. A copy of that drawing is forwarded herewith.

It was not until recently, that Indian Affairs gave any definite indication that attempts would be made to obtain the Indian properties mentioned, and it now appears that efforts are being directed toward obtaining the western parcel only. Mr. Healy's memorandum gives no assurance that their efforts will be successful.

A relatively small increase to the playground area would be possible if the westerly Indian property when surveyed shows a rectangular shape. The new building group could be moved northerly, but would place the easterly end of the new school immediately behind the dilapidated buildings to the east of the right of way. Considerable improvements to the layout of the school grounds would be effected if both properties could be made available, but in the event that no additional area can be made available, we cannot agree that any improvement would result from rearranging the layout which up to date has been the basis of establishing sewage and power lines and other mechanical services.

Memo.(c)

Mr. Healy's reference to the interview between Messrs. Healy and Phelan with our Chief Architect, has been discussed since the date of your notation on the memorandum. In the interview, Mr. Healy's statement that working drawings for the school would be completed during March, was interpreted to indicate that tenders could be invited at that time. It has been pointed out verbally in the last few days, to the Indian Affairs officers concerned, that following the completion of working drawings, specifications must be prepared and stencilled, drawings must be printed and assembled, approved wage rates must be obtained, and that a number of other routine operations must be carried out before tenders can be invited by public advertisement.

We propose directing every effort toward completing our work on this project as soon as possible, but with our unreasonably small staff depleted by the recent resignations of Mr. Horwood and Mr. Barnes, we are no longer prepared to estimate dates within which phases of our work will be completed.

May 15, 1947.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

We have been expecting you to visit us lately. Dr. Moore's visit was most pleasant and encouraging for our teachers. At the present moment, Mr. Wescott, our inspector, is examining our pupils. You will soon receive his report which we hope will be most satisfactory to the Department.

We have several requests to present before you and the members of the Indian Affairs Branch, and it is with complete trust in your kind interest that we do it.

May we have three dozen individual desks, largest size, for next Sept. for our seventh grades? We did not put this order on our requisition as we hope to have them by Sept. by asking you directly for them.

Prizes are given to our graduates in June. We have twelve this year. A money offering is usually given us by some of the graduates' parents, but this amount is far from covering the cost of prizes we like to give them. We also grant from six to ten prizes in each of the other twelve classes in our schools. Would the Department have the kindness to allow a certain amount to buy these prizes?

Our third request is a big item. When Mr. Doucet visited us last Fall we asked him whether we could hope to have a new convent immediately after the building of our new school. Mr. Doucet assured us that a new residence could not be expected before five years at least and that
most likely some one from the Department would come at the end of this school year to estimate the amount of repairs to be done in our present home. We have taken the initiative, Mr. Phelan, and have asked the estimate of painting the outside of our residence and of the inside, ground floor only, for this year. We have asked for separate estimates of the different sections of our house, hoping these would be more satisfactory to the Department. We feel sure, dear Mr. Phelan, that you and your co-workers in Ottawa, admit the urgent need of these repairs, so we are hopeful that a generous authorization will be given soon to do the work requested. This timely treatment will prevent the residence from falling into greater decay and will certainly improve its appearance and add value to it.

We are much worried over the present increase in the price of building material; however you and Mr. Doucet and even kind Mr. Hoey gave us such a great assurance that our new school would begin this summer, that we are looking forward to a day in the near future when we shall see the work begin.

We thank you, kind Sir, in advance, for the courtesy with which you will attend to the above mentioned points.

Yours sincerely,

Sr. Mary Albertine
Principal

June 2, 1947.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

We find attached to the last Indian Bulletin, a form to be filled out by the teachers who wish to remain on the teaching staff for the school year 1947-1948. At the present time it is impossible to assure the Department whether the same religious teachers who are teaching here actually will be stationed again in Caughnawaga, next September. The assignments for the next school year are received from our Reverend Superior General at the end of July. We shall then be able to give you definitely the names of the religious teachers who will be in Caugh. for the next school term. May we delay till the end of July to send in these applications or does the Department prefer we should fill them out now regardless of the fact that there might be a few changes in our staff during the coming summer vacation?

The Indian Bulletins have interested us very much this year. We find them instructive and enlightening. We highly appreciate the new salary scale and wish to express our deep gratitude immediately to the Department for this beneficent increase.

Dear Mr. Phelan, may we expect a favorable reply to our letter of the 15th ult.? We are still hopeful for a generous authorization from the members of the Indian Affairs Branch.

We assure you of our great interest and cooperation in the advancement of Indian Education.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Teachers' Residence,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.
July 17, 1947.

Dear Sir:

In our letter of July last to Mr. Doucet, we asked the latter to hasten the authorization for the painting of our house, so that the work might be done during the absence of most of our teachers.

May we renew our request today and ask you to have the kindness to tell your purchasing agent about our eagerness to receive the paint ordered by Mr. Saylor? Our teachers have left the Reserve for their retreat and for summer courses; it would be the ideal time to have at least the painting of the inside done.

We shall be most grateful to you, Sir, for this kindness. Our teachers were most pleased also to have made your acquaintance though it was on the last school day. We hope to have the pleasure of receiving you in our schools next year.

Yours sincerely,

Sisters of St. Ann.

[Signature]
Principal

We have an Indian ready to do the work and we are extremely anxious to secure the paint. Anything you can do to rush delivery will be appreciated.

Bernard F. Neary
Bupt. of Welfare & Training.

Caughnawaga, Que.,
January 19, 1948.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th ultimo dealing with voucher no. 1120 for $7.40 covering cost of transportation of children to the Caughnawaga Village School, in which you state that the original cost has been exceeded in almost all cases and in reply I wish to submit the following:

When the Bush Road School was closed in September 1947, it was understood that the children living in that area, who would have normally attended this school, would be transported to the different Village Schools. At that time the taxi driver was only going to one place, that is from the Village to Reserve Lot 325. A while after an Indian family purchased Reserve Lot No. 261 and as there are no school there but that it is in the Bush Rd., area we had to have their children transported, which meant that the route had to be extended from Reserve Lot no. 225 to 261-A-.

Later on the parents of pupils living on Chateauguay Basin Road up to Reserve lot no. 122 D and the same applied to the pupils living along the Chateauguay-Melone Highway as far as Reserve Lot 157. The additional mileage incurred means that the original mileage has been tripled but it also means that every Indian child living outside of the Village proper is well taken care of and that all roads are now covered. The only road not deserved by school transportation is that of St. Isidore but the children are attending the St. Isidore Road School which is opened and under Miss Descotesux. It is hoped that the above will meet with your approval. None of the parents can now claim that there is discrimination in the transportation of the pupils attending the Village Schools.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent,

MEMORANDUM

Re: Water Supply,
Twelve-roomed Indian Day School,
Caughsawage Indian Agency, Quebec.

March 3, 1948.

In connection with Mr. Hoey's memorandum to you of February 25th last, which carried your marginal notation of February 27th, 1948, comment is advanced as follows:

Prior to destruction by fire in 1941, the school at Caughsawage which is being replaced, drew its water supply from a well drilled immediately to the rear of the building in close proximity to the buried fuel tank serving the school heating system. Before the fire, it had become evident, that the tank had corroded badly and had permitted the surrounding subsoil to become saturated with fuel oil, which was finding its way into the well, fouling the water supply. Any water drawn from a school faucet showed oil, and was unfit for domestic use.

In considering a source of water supply for construction purposes, our Chief Architect felt that it would be desirable to investigate the existing well, (in disuse for seven years) as a source of supply, rather than authorize the contractor to pump water from the St. Lawrence River, and the matter was discussed with Col. Neary by Mr. Buck. It was thought the well could have sufficient volume, and there was no evidence of oil, it would at least serve the contractor's purposes, and might possibly be satisfactory for use in the new school. Col. Neary concurred, and requested Indian Agent Brisebois at Caughsawage to contact a firm who would supply an estimate for having the well shaft cleaned out, and a pumping test put on. Mr. Brisebois has now replied, and most of his letter has been quoted by Mr. Hoey in his memorandum.

When Mr. Brisebois furnishes Indian Affairs with a tender, it will be considered and you will be advised.

Chief Engineer.

I wish to refer to your letter of the 9th instant dealing with the testing of the well at the site of the former Senior School at Caughnawaga in which you advised that the employment of Jean Bedard Ltd. had been accepted and that an expenditure of $285.00 approved for this undertaking. In connection with this work I beg to report as follows:

The well in question was located inside the destroyed building, in the boiler room, 9 feet below the ground level and only fifteen feet from the site where the old oil tank seeped (500 gallons of oil went into the ground when it pierced).

When the contractor came to start the pumping it was found out that the five inches pipe of the well was tightly blocked with mortar, bricks and other debris. An attempt was made to clear same but to no avail. Moreover an heavy coat of oil could be seen on top of the water.

Owing to the condition of the well and the impossibility to clear the debris, the work was ordered discontinued and the following suggestion made.

That a new well be drilled nearer the site of the proposed building where we would be assured that the water would be good for drinking purposes which well would not cost more than $400.00 or $450.00 and would no doubt be sufficient for the use of the contractor.

If this suggestion is accepted a well could be drilled immediately and be ready when the work of the new building commences.

Re: Water Supply and Fire Protection, Twelve-roomed School, Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Quebec.

In order to obtain material for a reply to your memorandum of April 12th last, an officer of this Division made an investigation on the site on the 14th instant, with a view to securing additional data relative to the acquisition by Indian Affairs of additional property, the water supply and fire protection for the school.

Collaborating with our officer, Mr. G.R. Rankin, were Mr. G.H. Edgcumbe of the Dominion Health and Welfare Department in Montreal, and Messrs. Caley and Owen of the Geological Survey Division of this Department. The precis of our officer's report follows.

LAND -

We are given to understand that Lot 100 in the Village may be obtained. This is the lot on which it is desired eventually to build the proposed Teachers' Residence and is adequate for the purpose. Lots 83 and 84 to the east of the site entrance can not be obtained in the immediate future and will be the concern of the Indian Affairs Branch. These lots would give additional frontage, but are not required at present. Every effort possible however should be directed by Indian Affairs toward acquiring the property as soon as possible, with a view to improving the appearance of the area, and to justify its selection as the site of the new and costly building.

WATER SUPPLY -

An inspection was made of four drilled wells in the vicinity and of the old well on the site. Information was also obtained from Mr. Joseph Laberge who has drilled practically all the wells in these parts. Mr. Laberge is well known to contracting firms in Montreal, and his information is considered reliable. Rock stratum is encountered from ten feet to twelve feet below the surface, and the wells then drilled through solid rock. The wells inspected were fifty, fifty-two, fifty-eight and sixty feet deep, which appeared to be the approximate average drilled depth for public wells provided for the Indian families in the Village. The old well on the school site is 100'-0" deep, and it must be assumed that a new well would at least reach this depth, since a much greater volume is required than for public wells mentioned.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
WATER SUPPLY (Cont'd)

The best information available on the assumed capacity of a well 100 feet deep on the site is 1,000 gallons per hour for a five inch well and 3,000 to 4,000 gallons per hour for an eight inch well. Our specifications call for delivery of 540 gallons of water per hours, and unless this rate of flow is obtained from a five inch well the bore should be enlarged to eight inches. Until the well is drilled and given a seventy-two hour test and the draw-down level ascertained, no positive information will be available. The possibility exists that the well may have to be bored deeper, or a new location chosen and the process repeated until the available visible volume is adequate for our purposes. It is not thought, however, that this will be the case.

The possibility of oil from the old well impregnating the new supply is negligible. While the existence of oil in the well shaft is still visible, it is felt that since the desired position of the new well would be higher, and 180 feet northwest of the old well, that if the bottom of the well casing is cemented to the solid rock, no penetration of oil from the latter will be possible.

The matter of obtaining potable water from Lake St. Louis was investigated, including a discussion with the Montreal Water Works Department. Information gathered indicated that the raw sewage and industrial wastes from plants situated along the south shore of the St. Lawrence River, the Chateauguay River and surrounding Lake St. Louis, make the treatment of such water for a project as small as the new school, so elaborate and expensive to operate and maintain with expert staff, that it is not being considered.

Mr. Edgecombe took seven samples of water for analysis, and confirmation of the above. Mr. Caley examined the site and was shown our proposed location for the new well. The location of the new well (to be located in a projection of the new boiler house) is shown on our revised plan index number 600, sheet W.1, dated May 20, 1947; blueprints of which have previously been sent to the Indian Affairs Branch. Mr. Caley stated that he would submit a separate report on his own observations to this Branch as soon as possible.

FIRE PROTECTION -

It was not understood previously that the Caughnawaga Agency has an arrangement with the City of Lachine Fire Department to answer calls to the Reserve. In view of this, it is felt that the costly undertaking of constructing a pipe line and intake to Lake St. Louis might not be necessary as Lachine is approximately only four miles distant, and the fire brigade can arrive at the site of the school in about fifteen minutes.

One serious difficulty in utilizing fire hose within the school building is that fire fighting would depend almost entirely on the female staff and pupils. Control of pupils in such an emergency has been described by Indian Superintendent Brisebois as an impossibility.

There is little that is combustible in the school and the boiler house, and the use of conveniently placed fire extinguishers of an approved type should control a fire until the fire brigade arrive. Fire extinguishers moreover in sufficient numbers can be handled by the female staff. The stand pipes and hose within the school have outside connection, to which the firemen may connect their fire hose, which would be
laid to Lake St. Louis, a distance of some 460 feet. Through their pumper, water streams can be employed in the number and at the pressure required.

The alternative, of course, would be to construct an underground reservoir of say 10,000 gallons capacity to be served from the new well and equipped with a fire pump and in a separate pump house. This would mean constant employment of men able to, and available to put the pump in use and operate the hose within the school for the time required for the arrival of the Lachine fire equipment, or for the twenty or thirty minutes required to exhaust the contents of the reservoir. This alternative is not recommended, and unless requested, we are not estimating the cost of construction.

Summing up, the cost of providing a water supply for domestic purposes from a deep well cased to solid rock would be as follows: For drilling a five inch well, the cost would be $4.50 per foot, and for an eight inch well $8.00 per foot. For every foot beyond one hundred feet in depth, the additional cost would be $1.00. For supplying and installing steel casing for a five inch well, the cost would be $1.10 per foot. In addition to drilling the well a seventy-two hour test should be undertaken to ascertain: (a) the capacity in gallons per hour; (b) the quality of the water; (c) that the supply would be adequate for a long period. This type of work is undertaken throughout Canada by the Railway and Power Corporation Limited of Montreal whose charge would be $300.00 for the complete testing operation. The total cost, therefore, on our assumption that water would be obtained at one hundred feet, would be about $350.00 for a five inch well.

It is recommended, therefore, that we be authorized to have the drilling and casing of a five inch well, one hundred feet deep undertaken by Joseph Laberge, and if water is found at that level, to have the before-mentioned test carried out by Railway and Power Corporation Limited. The work to be under the supervision of Indian Superintendent Brisebois, who would be furnished with all necessary instructions from this office.

The cost of pumps and other water supply equipment is already included in the contract being awarded, and the cost of other material and services recommended herein can be met from the contingencies amount we have requested from Council.

Chief Engineer.

Ottawa, July 7, 1946.

Memorandum:

Re: New Senior Day School, Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Quebec.

You are advised that during a telephone conversation on July 5th between Mr. E. F. Neary, of the Indian Affairs Branch, and Mr. V. Hoey, of this Division, the question of providing an automatic alarm at the Lachine Fire Station, in case of a fire at the above school was discussed. Mr. Neary was of the opinion that a system such as we proposed, which would summon fire fighting equipment with a minimum loss of time, should be adopted.

Provision has been made for the installation of two siamese water pipe connections at the school, to which the Lachine Fire Department's water pumping equipment could be connected, to feed the fire standpipe within the building in the event of a fire. We consider it advisable to connect the electric fire alarm system provided for the school to the Lachine Fire Station alarm call board, so that in the event of the sounding of the fire alarm system at the school, fire fighting equipment would be automatically summoned, thus removing the possibility of delay which could result from relying on telephone contact between the school and fire station.

Connections between the school and the Lachine Fire Department Station should be arranged for through the Bell Telephone Company, and it is suggested that the Indian Affairs Branch contact the Lachine Fire Chief and the Montreal office of the Bell Telephone Company in the near future to arrange for such a service.

It will be necessary for the Bell Telephone Company to carry their telephone lines to the building for the telephone to be located in the Principal's office, and we suggest that Indian Affairs make application for the telephone service at the same time enquiries are directed in connection with the fire alarm system.

Early attention is recommended in this matter, so that the contractor can be advised of the conduit runs he will be required to provide in the floor slab during the building construction for the telephone service and for the fire alarm connections if the Indian Affairs Branch approve of this suggestion.

T. S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

R. A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Re:- Steam Boiler, Eastern School,
Caughnawaga Indian Agency.

I beg to refer to previous correspondence dealing with the repairing of the boiler at the above named School and in this connection to advise that it is not possible to replace the base of the boiler as this type has been discontinued. The Gurney Foundry Co., Ltd., do not make them any longer. This boiler was made about thirty years ago.

May I say however that a base of fire bricks could be installed to replace the corroded steel one. This would be satisfactory for at least two or three years and its cost, including materials and labour, would be of approximately $75.00.

Please authorize the above at your earliest convenience. Said work could be made on a weekend and would not inconvenience the teaching staff nor the pupils.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Supt., Indian Agency.
October 21, 1948.

Mr. Frs. Brisebois,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

Bernard F. Neary

For your information and transmission to Indian Affairs, the following outlined description of the plant is given.

The boiler plant is designed to heat the new day school and has capacity to also serve a future teachers residence block. It is composed of the following items of equipment:

- 2-7000 square feet E.D.R. low pressure steam steel fire box boilers arranged for stoker firing.
- 2-screw feed underfeed stokers each having a capacity to burn a maximum of 350 lbs of coal per hour and controlled by pressure-trols set to maintain the operating pressure of 7 lbs per square inch at the boiler.
- 1 - horizontal type condensation pump and receiver with a capacity to handle 15000 square feet E.D.R.
- 1 - deep well pump arranged to discharge into an adjacent concrete cistern.
- 1 - shallow well type pump arranged to pump from the cistern into a pressure tank.

cubic feet of air per minute. In conjunction with the air washer, there is one general supply fan having a capacity to handle 17,000 cubic feet of air per minute and one general exhaust fan having a capacity to handle 15,000 cubic feet of air per minute.

A toilet exhaust system is handled separately by a fan having a capacity to handle 2160 cubic feet of air per minute.

The operating engineer should be required to carry out the normal maintenance duties in connection with the foregoing equipment and system, and it is recommended that an operating engineer having fourth class papers be asked for, subject to the approval of the Civil Service Commission.

Ottawa, December 13, 1948.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS & DEVELOPMENT SERVICES

Re: Caretaker - Caughnawaga School.

Your I.A. 1256-24 of November 12, 1948.

Your memorandum was forwarded to Mr. Indian Superintendent Brisebois so that he could intelligently review the problem of hiring a competently trained caretaker for this building now under construction.

We have now received a reply from him indicating that there are no Indians at Caughnawaga holding engineers fourth class papers. However, Mr. Brisebois advises as follows:

"We have on the Reserve a very reliable and capable member of the Band, namely, Mr. Wilfred Rice, aged 42 years. Mr. Rice has been in the employ of the Kanawaki Golf Club for the past 24 years as General Supervisor of the Golf course and also as maintenance man for the buildings together with all their mechanical apparatus, such as their Electrical Plumbing Equipment, Automatic Fire Sprinkler, Furnaces, etc.

"This man is an expert mechanic, good plumber and has a good knowledge of electrical work. Mr. Rice could see to the entire maintenance of all the different types..."
of machinery including pumps, stokers, ventilating system, filters, controls, etc.

"Although not having the papers mentioned in Mr. Mills' memorandum it is believed that Mr. Rice, who is conversant with the operation of low pressure boilers would be suitable for this position."

Mr. Brisebois recommends that Mr. Rice be interviewed by an engineer of the Department at some future date when one of your officials is inspecting the new building.

Acting Director.

Estate of John Phillips.

Your memorandum of January 4 concerning the estate of John Phillips has been referred to me for my information. While we have no further use for this school nor for the school building, I would appreciate being advised on the following points:

Dear Sir:

I understand that one of our engineers has recently discussed with you the possibility of providing an automatic fire protection signal system for our new Indian Day School now under construction at Caughnawaga. At that time it was suggested that an official letter be sent to you concerning the points raised at this meeting.

Our proposal is that in the school there be installed an alarm which would be connected with your fire station at Lachine. Then, in the event of a fire at the school, a signal would automatically be sent, registering on your alarm board and thus calling your equipment. We are quite prepared to accept the fact that your Fire Chief would have to decide at that time whether he could despatch equipment without interfering with other fire fighting being engaged in by his department. In other words, we appreciate the fact that our requirements would be secondary to those in Lachine.

In view of the facts presented above, I would like to hear from you as to whether such a system could be installed in your fire station connecting it with our new Caughnawaga Indian Day School.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
Ottawa, February 21, 1949.

Dear Sir:

I understand that one of our engineers discussed with you the possibility of providing an automatic fire protection alarm system for our new Indian Day School now under construction at Caughnawaga. At that time, it was suggested that an official letter be sent to you concerning the points raised at the meeting.

As you are aware, the Lachine Fire Department has in the past offered all assistance possible in providing fire fighting facilities for the Caughnawaga Indian Agency. When requested to do so. In connection with the fire protection at the school, we have provided two (2) Siamese connections at the front of the school of suitable thread and design for connecting to the Lachine Fire Department's pumper. A two inch (2") line is run from each Siamese connection each feeding one vertical standpipe servicing one hose cabinet on each of the three floors. The two 2" vertical standpipes are inter-connected so that one pumper at either Siamese connection may be used to supply water to the six (6) hose cabinets. We have provided an electric fire alarm system with two (2) "break glass" fire alarm stations in the corridors of the 3rd floor and our proposal is to connect this system with the fire alarm panel in the Lachine Fire Station so that in the event of fire an alarm will automatically be sounded when the school circuit is energized indicating the need for fire fighting equipment. It is our feeling that all possibility of delay in transmitting the call should be eliminated as far as possible, and in our opinion, the method proposed is a reliable means of accomplishing this end.

We are quite prepared to accept the fact that your Fire Chief would have to decide at the time of receiving an alarm if the equipment and personnel is available to send to the Caughnawaga school. In other words, we appreciate the fact that our requirements will be secondary to those of the City of Lachine.

In view of the facts presented above, I would like to hear from you as to whether the City of Lachine authorities would be agreeable to having the necessary equipment installed in the Fire Station to provide this service, the costs of which would be entirely borne by the Department.

Yours Sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

HIS MAJESTY, with the advice and consent of the Legislative Council and of the Legislative Assembly of Quebec, enacts as follows:

1.—The Stationary Enginemen's Act (Revised Statutes, 1941, chapter 178) is replaced by the following:

CHAPTER 178

AN ACT RELATING TO STATIONARY ENGINEMEN

1.—This act may be cited as the Stationary Enginemen Act.

DIVISION I

DEFINITIONS

2.—In this act:
1° The words "stationary engine" include:
a) Steam boilers;
b) Steam engines;
c) Stationary internal combustion engines of over twenty-five mechanical horsepower;
d) Refrigerating apparatus operated by motors of a total power exceeding twenty-five mechanical horsepower;

* Assented to, May 13th, 1942.
The piping and accessories used for operating the above mentioned engines.

Such words do not, however, include:

a) Steam boilers used for heating buildings other than public buildings contemplated by the Public Building Safety Act* (Chap. 170) or industrial establishments contemplated by the Industrial and Commercial Establishments Act** (Chap. 175);

b) Boilers with safety-valves set at a pressure of not more than fifteen pounds per square inch, with a capacity not exceeding seventy-five horsepower and a heating surface not exceeding one thousand one hundred and twenty-five square feet;

c) Boilers, used elsewhere than at buildings under construction, with safety-valves, set at a pressure of over fifteen pounds per square inch, but with a capacity not exceeding fifteen horsepower and a heating surface not exceeding two hundred and twenty-five square feet;

2° The words "stationary engineman" mean any person who directs or supervises the operation of a stationary engine or attends to the maintenance or inspection thereof;

3° The word "Minister" means the Minister of Labour;

4° The word "regulations" means the regulations made under this act.

DIVISION II

EXAMINERS

3.—The Lieutenant-Governor in Council may appoint not more than three examiners, of whom one shall be chief examiner, as well as a secretary and the employees necessary for the carrying out of this act, and may fix their salaries in accordance with the Outside Service Act (Chap. 12).

4.—The examiners so appointed shall constitute the board of examiners. Such board shall be under the control of the Minister.

5.—The salaries of the examiners, the secretary and the other employees and the travelling and administrative expenses...
shall be paid out of the moneys voted annually, for that purpose, by the Legislature.

6.—The chief examiner shall make an annual report to the Minister.

7.—The examiners shall hold the examinations and issue the certificates. They shall keep registers in which shall be entered the names of enginemen who have passed the examinations, and also of the candidates and the amount of the fees collected. They shall preserve in their archives a copy of the answers of each candidate to the examination questions.

8.—Any examiner or any inspector, appointed for the carrying out of this act, may, at any hour, enter and pass over any property where there is a stationary engine, for the purpose of ascertaining whether this act and the regulations are being observed.

DIVISION III

CERTIFICATES

9.—No person shall work as a stationary engineman unless he holds a certificate of the class established for his work by the regulations.

10.—Every person having, as owner, lessee or user or otherwise, charge of a stationary engine must:

a) Entrust stationary enginemen's work only to persons having the required certificate;

b) Keep such engine, when in operation, under the supervision of a stationary engineman;

c) Facilitate the inspector's work.

11.—No stationary engineman who holds the certificate required by this act and the regulations shall be obliged to undergo any other examination or to obtain a license or a certificate of qualification from any municipal authority.

DIVISION IV

REGULATIONS

12.—The Lieutenant-Governor in Council may make such regulations as he may deem necessary for the proper carrying of this act and particularly for the following purposes:

a) To define the different classes of certificates contemplated in section 9;

b) To define the conditions for the issuing of certificates;

c) To define the nature of the examinations and the subjects which they may cover;

d) To fix the period for which the certificates shall be valid and the conditions of their renewal;

e) To establish fees for the issuing and renewal of certificates and for admission to the examinations;

f) To determine the manner of establishing the capacity of stationary engines;
g) To enact any other provisions to facilitate the work of the examiners and increase the efficiency of the service.

Such regulations shall come into force after their publication in the Quebec Official Gazette.

DIVISION V

CONTRAVICTIONS

13.—In addition to the penal prosecutions hereinafter prescribed, suit may be brought to recover from any stationary engineman the fee payable on the renewal of his certificate, if he acts in that capacity without having discharged such obligation.

14.—Every person who contravenes any provisions of this act or of the regulations shall be liable to a fine of twenty-five to one hundred dollars and costs, and, in default of payment of such fine and costs, to an imprisonment not exceeding three months.

15.—All penal prosecutions under this act shall be brought by the Attorney-General.

The procedure shall be that prescribed by the Quebec Summary Convictions Act (Chap. 29).

16.—No evidence shall be admitted to establish that prosecution was brought as the result of a complaint or to discover the identity of the informer.

17.—This act shall not apply to mines contemplated by the Quebec Mining Act (Revised Statutes, 1941, chapter 196).

2.—This act shall come into force on the day of its sanction.

REGULATIONS UNDER THE STATIONARY ENGINEER'S ACT

1.—In the present regulations:
   a.—The term "horse power" or the abbreviation "H.P." indicates the capacity of a boiler computed according to the regulations.
   b.—The term "motor horse power" or the abbreviation "M.H.P." indicates the capacity of engines computed according to the regulations.
   c.—The term "ton of refrigeration" indicates the capacity of refrigerating machines calculated according to the regulations.

2.—The capacity of a boiler is based on the heating surface, in square feet, and is calculated in the following manner:
   a.—For boilers equipped with mechanical stokers having forced or induced draft, pulverized coal burners, gas or oil burners:

| Type of boiler       | Heating surface (in square feet) | H.P. |
|----------------------|----------------------------------|------|
| Fire-tube boilers    | 12                               | 1    |
| Internal fire-box boilers | 11                           | 1    |
| Water-tube boilers   | 8½                              | 1    |

   b.—For hand-fired boilers, equipped with a blower or not:

| Type of boiler       | Heating surface (in square feet) | H.P. |
|----------------------|----------------------------------|------|
| Fire-tube boilers    | 15                               | 1    |
| Internal fire-box boilers | 13½                          | 1    |
| Water-tube boilers   | 10                               | 1    |

c.—In the case of electric boilers, one horse power is equivalent to ten (10) kilowatt-hour or the output of three thousand four hundred and thirteen (3,413) B.T.U.

3.—a.—The capacity of steam engines is calculated by the following formula:

\[ \text{PLAN} = \frac{33,000}{P; \text{the effective pressure in pounds per square inch, based on } \frac{1}{4} (25\%) \text{ cut-off};} \]

\[ L; \text{the length of the stroke, in feet;} \]

\[ A; \text{the net area of the piston, in square inches;} \]

\[ N; \text{the number of revolutions per minute.} \]

b.—The capacity of Diesel-type internal combustion engines is calculated by the following formula:

\[ \frac{D^2 \times N}{2.5} \]

\[ D; \text{the diameter of the cylinder, in inches;} \]

\[ N; \text{the number of cylinders;} \]

\[ 2.5; \text{a constant.} \]

c.—The capacity of steam turbines is calculated by the recognized formula.

4.—The capacity of a refrigerating machine is computed according to the capacity of the engine actuating it, as follows:

   a.—If the refrigerant used in carbon dioxide (CO₂), the capacity is one (1) ton for 2 M.H.P.;
   b.—If another refrigerant is used, the capacity is one (1) ton for 1.5 M.H.P.;
   c.—When the machine is used for air-conditioning and liquid-cooling (with the exception of...
brines), the capacity is one (1) ton for 1 M.H.P. for any kind of refrigerant.

5.—An "A installation" includes any installation consisting of steam boilers; steam reciprocating pumps; belt-actuated pumps; automatic stokers; pulverised coal burners, blowers; compressors of all kinds actuated by motors other than steam engines and any control apparatus. The installations of this category are grouped according to their capacity, pursuant to the provisions of sections 30, 32, 34 and 36.

6.—An "AB installation" includes any installation consisting of steam boilers, steam engines, steam turbines. The installations of this category are grouped according to their capacity, pursuant to the provisions of sections 31, 33, 35 and 37.

7.—A steam boiler installation is considered in operation when the boilers are under pressure and the fires not extinguished or banked; fires cannot be considered as banked when the fuel is stacked in the front, rear or sides in such a way that heat is emitted in sufficient quantity to evaporate water when all valves are closed.

Certificates

8.—Certificates are valid from their date of issue to the thirty-first of March following.

9.—Stationary enginemen shall post their certificate in the boiler or engine room in which they work; failure to comply with this regulation entail the cancelling of the certificate.

10.—Stationary enginemen shall, upon receipt of their certificate, sign their name in the space reserved for that purpose; unsigned certificates are considered as void.

11.—Certificates shall be renewed before May 1st of each year; stationary enginemen wishing to renew their certificate shall return same to the Board of Examiners. However, the inspector's certificate is not subject to renewal.

12.—Stationary enginemen not having renewed their certificate for three consecutive years shall undergo a new examination.

13.—The holder of a certificate of inspector desiring to carry on the work of the stationary engineman must renew his first-class certificate.

14.—The Board of Examiners may cancel or suspend a certificate for a given period, if the holder:

a.—is habitually intemperate or addicted to the use of drugs; or

b.—becomes insane or physically incapacitated; or

c.—has proved incompetent or grossly negligent in the execution of his duties; or

d.—has obtained his certificate through fraud or misrepresentation; or

e.—has helped one or more persons to obtain a certificate fraudulently; or

f.—allows another person to use his certificate; or

g.—alters or allows others to alter his certificate.

15.—The Board of Examiners may decide to issue a certificate, without examination, to a stationary engineman holding a certificate issued by the Government of another province of the Dominion; such certificate shall authorize him to take charge of a stationary engine; The Board of Examiners shall however require proofs of
competency, good conduct and sobriety and a fee of $5.00 for the issue of this certificate which is valid for a period of twelve (12) months only. After expiration of this certificate, the holder, if he desires to keep on working as stationary engineman, shall comply with the provisions of sections 16, 17, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 26 and 27 of the present regulations.

Examinations

16.—Any person wishing to obtain a certificate as stationary engineman shall present a request to that purpose according to the form issued by the Board of Examiners. The candidate shall enclose reference from his past and actual employers; such references shall be countersigned by the engineman under whose direction the candidate worked or has worked. If the Board finds the candidate eligible, it shall notify him of the place, the date and the time of his examination.

17.—To obtain his certificate, the candidate shall:
   a.—have to be a British subject;
   b.—furnish the Board of Examiners with sufficient proof as to his character and sobriety;
   c.—obtain at least seventy per cent (70%) of the points allowed to the answers;
   d.—pay the required fees.

18.—Examination shall be passed in the localities designated by the Minister; the Board sets the dates of such examinations and notifies the candidates.

19.—The candidates shall answer in writing, in French or in English, to the questions put to them; the Board of Examiners shall keep in its files the text of the examinations.

20.—All candidates for an inspector's certificate shall speak French and English fluently; as for the other certificates, a sufficient knowledge of either language is necessary.

21.—The Board of Examiners may require, besides the written examination, that the candidates for the third and fourth class certificate undergo verbal examination and that the candidates for all the classes give proof of their practical knowledge in a stationary engine installation.

22.—The Board of Examiners may exact that the answers of the candidate be accompanied by proper sketches.

23.—Candidates to a class higher than the fourth must know how to read and write French or English; he shall answer himself to the questions stated. A candidate undergoing fourth class examination may, however, have his answers written by a person other than a stationary engineman. The choice of such person must be approved by the Board.

24.—Candidates for the first class or the inspector's certificates may, during the examinations, refer to technical books but the books so used must be approved by the examiners, before the examination.

25.—The maximum duration of the examinations is the following for each one of the classes hereinafter mentioned:

| Class          | Duration of the examination |
|----------------|----------------------------|
| Inspector      | six consecutive days        |
| First class    | four consecutive days        |
| Second class   | three consecutive days       |
| Third class    | two consecutive days         |
| Fourth class   | one day                     |
26.—In case of failure, the candidate may undergo another examination only after a delay of ninety days following the date of his first examination; moreover, should he not undergo the examination in the week following such delay the prescribed fees shall be charged again unless he has obtained an extension.

27.—The fees for the examination and the renewal of the certificates are the following:

| Inspector                    | $25.00 |
| First class                  | $15.00 |
| Second class                 | $10.00 |

| ator                        |       |

| Butter or cheese dairy—sta-  | $2.00  |
