Classification of certificates

28.—The certificates of stationary enginemen are divided into classes and grades corresponding to the nature and capacity of the plant.

29.—Inspector's certificate:—The holder of this certificate may, under the direction of the Board of Examiners, make the inspection of stationary engines and of all apparatus governed by the Pressure Vessels' Act.

30.—First class certificate, grade A:—The holder of this certificate may take charge of any heating plant.

31.—First class certificate, grade AB:—The holder of this certificate may take charge of any heating or power plant.

32.—Second class certificate, grade A:—The holder of this certificate may:

a.—take charge of any heating plant providing the boiler capacity does not exceed six hundred H.P. (600);

b.—work in a first-class plant, grade A, under the direction of a qualified engineman;

c.—take charge of any plant consisting exclusively of electric boilers, whatever be its capacity.

33.—Second class certificate, grade AB:—The holder of this certificate may:

a.—take charge of any heating or power plant providing the boiler capacity does not exceed six hundred (600) H.P., and the engine capacity, five hundred (500) M.H.P.;

b.—work in a first class plant, grade A or AB, under the direction of a qualified engineman;

c.—take charge of any plant consisting exclusively of electric boilers.

34.—Third class certificate, grade A:—The holder of this certificate may:
a.—take charge of any heating plant providing the boiler capacity does not exceed four hundred (400) H.P.;
b.—work in a second class plant, grade A, under the direction of a qualified engineman;
c.—take charge of any plant consisting exclusively of electric boilers with a maximum capacity of six hundred (600) H.P.

35.—Third class certificate, grade AB:—The holder of this certificate may:
a.—take charge of any heating or power plant providing the boiler capacity does not exceed four hundred (400) H.P. and that of the steam engines, three hundred and fifty (350) M.H.P.;
b.—work in a second class plant, grade A or AB, under the direction of a qualified engineman;
c.—take charge of any plant consisting exclusively of electric boilers with a maximum capacity of six hundred (600) H.P.

36.—Fourth class certificate, grade A:—The holder of this certificate may:
a.—take charge of any heating plant providing the boiler capacity does not exceed two hundred (200) H.P.;
b.—work in a third class plant, grade A, under the direction of a qualified engineman;
c.—take charge of any plant consisting exclusively of electric boilers with a maximum capacity of four hundred (400) H.P.

37.—Fourth class certificate, grade AB:—The holder of this certificate may:
a.—take charge of any heating or power plant providing the boiler capacity does not exceed two hundred (200) H.P. and that of the engines, one hundred and fifty (150) M.H.P.;
b.—work in a third class plant, grade A or AB, under the direction of a qualified engineman;
c.—take charge of any plant consisting exclusively of electric boilers with a maximum capacity of four hundred (400) H.P.

38.—Stationary engineman's certificate—butter or cheese dairy:—The holder of this certificate may take charge of steam boilers with a maximum capacity of thirty (30) H.P. and of engines with a maximum capacity of thirty (30) M.H.P. providing such machines be installed in a butter or cheese dairy.

39.—Stationary engineman's certificate—sawmills:—The holder of this certificate may take charge of a plant providing the boiler capacity does not exceed two hundred (200) H.P. and that of the steam engines, one hundred and twenty-five (125) M.H.P.

40.—Portable engineman's certificate:—The holder of this certificate may take charge of portable steam machines.

41.—Refrigerating machine operator's certificate "R":—The holder of this certificate may take charge of any refrigerating machine which is not actuated by a steam engine; such certificate is subdivided in grades corresponding to the capacity of the plant in tons of refrigeration:
a.—Grade R-1:—The holder of this certificate may take charge of any plant;
b.—Grade R-2:—The holder of this certificate may take charge of a plant with a maximum capacity of one hundred and fifty (150) tons of
refrigeration and he may also work in a first class plant under the direction of a qualified operator;

c.—Grade R-8:—The holder of this certificate may take charge of a plant with a maximum capacity of one hundred (100) tons of refrigeration and he may also work in a second class plant under the direction of a qualified operator;

d.—Grade R-4:—The holder of this certificate may take charge of a plant with a maximum capacity of fifty (50) tons of refrigeration and he may also work in a third class plant under the direction of a qualified operator.

42.—Refrigerating machine operator's certificate, "RV":—The holder of this certificate may take charge of any refrigerating machine. This certificate is subdivided in grades corresponding to the capacity of the plant in tons of refrigeration. This certificate is given, free of charge, to any holder of an AB certificate who undergoes a special examination as to his knowledge of refrigerating machines.

a.—Grade RV-1:—The holder of this certificate may take charge of any plant.

b.—Category RV-2:—The holder of this certificate may take charge of a plant with a maximum capacity of one hundred and fifty (150) tons of refrigeration and he may also work in a first class plant under the direction of a qualified operator;

c.—Grade RV-3:—The holder of this certificate may take charge of a plant with a maximum capacity of one hundred (100) tons of refrigeration and he may also work in a second class plant under the direction of a qualified operator;

d.—Grade RV-4:—The holder of this certificate may take charge of a plant with a maximum capacity of fifty (50) tons of refrigeration and he may also work in a third class plant under the direction of a qualified operator.

43.—Diesel engine operator's certificate:—The holder of this certificate may take charge of Diesel-type internal combustion engines.

Qualifications of candidates

44.—Inspector examination:—The candidate who desires to obtain a certificate as pressure vessel inspector must hold a first class stationary engineman's certificate and be able to:

a.—make any calculations requested by the examiners;

b.—prove that he has a thorough knowledge of the codes used by the Board of Examiners;

c.—speak French and English fluently;

d.—make any scale drawing of steam boilers, steam engines and their auxiliaries.

45.—First class examination, grade A:—Any candidate to this examination must:

a.—have held a second class certificate, grade A, for at least twenty-four (24) months;

b.—have worked during twenty-four (24) months in minimum periods of three (3) consecutive months, under the direction of a stationary engineman holding a first class certificate, grade A, in a first class plant, grade A;

c.—have a sufficient knowledge of the pressure vessel Codes used by the Board of Examiners;

d.—be able to make a scale drawing of steam boiler or engine parts.
46.—First class examination, grade AB:—Candidates to this examination must:

a.—have held a second class certificate, grade AB, for at least twenty-four (24) months;

b.—have worked during twenty-four (24) months in minimum periods of three (3) consecutive months, under the direction of a stationary engineman holding a first class certificate, grade AB, in a first class plant, grade AB;

c.—have a sufficient knowledge of the pressure vessel Codes used by the Board of Examiners;

d.—be able to make a scale drawing of steam boiler or engine parts.

47.—Second class examination, grade A:—Candidates to this examination must:

a.—have held a third class certificate, grade A or AB, for at least twenty-four (24) months;

b.—have worked during twenty-four (24) months in minimum periods of three (3) consecutive months, under the direction of a stationary engineman holding at least a second class certificate, grades A or AB, in a plant of the second class, at least, grade A or AB.

48.—Second class examination, grade AB:—Candidates to this examination must:

a.—have held a third class certificate, grade AB, for at least twenty-four (24) months;

b.—have worked during twenty-four (24) months in minimum periods of three (3) consecutive months, under the direction of a stationary engineman holding, at least, a second class certificate, grade AB, in a plant of the second class, at least, grade AB.

50.—Third class examination, grade AB:—Candidates to this examination must:

a.—have held a fourth class certificate, grade AB, for at least eighteen (18) months;

b.—have worked during eighteen (18) months in minimum periods of three (3) consecutive months, under the direction of a stationary engineman holding, at least, a third class certificate, grade A or AB, in a plant of the third class, at least, grade A or AB.

Any candidate eligible to the third class examination, grade A, and who has worked during at least nine (9) months in a plant of grade AB, under the direction of a stationary engineman, may also undergo this examination.

However, any candidate having served an apprenticeship period of four (4) years in the construction or repair of boilers or steam engines...
shall be eligible to the third class examination without having, previously, undergone a fourth class examination, grade A or AB.

51.—Fourth class examination, grade A:—Candidates to this examination must:

a.—be at least twenty (20) years of age;

b.—have worked, as fireman, during eighteen (18) months in minimum periods of three (3) consecutive months, under the direction of a stationary engineman, in a stationary engine plant of grade A.

52.—Fourth class examination, grade AB:—Candidates to this examination must:

a.—be at least twenty (20) years of age;

b.—have worked, as fireman, during eighteen (18) months, in minimum periods of three (3) consecutive months, under the direction of a stationary engineman, in a stationary engines plant of grade AB.

Any candidate eligible to the fourth class examination, grade A, and who has worked, as fireman, during at least six (6) months in a plant of grade AB, under the direction of a stationary engineman, may also undergo this examination.

53.—Examination of stationary enginemen—butter or cheese dairy:—Candidates to this examination must:

a.—be at least twenty (20) years of age;

b.—have sufficient knowledge of stationary engines used in butter and cheese dairies.

54.—Examination of stationary enginemen—sawmills:—Candidates to this examination must:

a.—be at least twenty (20) years of age;

b.—have sufficient knowledge of stationary engines used in sawmills.

55.—Examinations of portable machine operators:—Candidates to this examination must:

a.—be at least eighteen (18) years of age and have worked a minimum of eighteen (18) months under the direction of a portable machine operator;

b.—have sufficient knowledge concerning the operation of portable machines used in construction work.

56.—Examination of refrigerating machine operators:—Candidates to this examination must be at least eighteen (18) years of age and have worked a minimum of twenty-four (24) months under the direction of a refrigerating machine operator holding a certificate as such; the Board of Examiners shall issue a certificate of the grade corresponding to the capacity of the plant where the candidate is employed after it has taken note of the reference furnished.

For promotion from one grade to the next grade higher, a candidate must:

a.—have held his certificate during at least twelve (12) months;

b.—have worked at least six (6) months in a refrigerating installation of a tonnage exceeding that allowed by the certificate which he now holds;

c.—have made this stage under the supervision of a person holding a certificate of a higher grade than the one he possesses.
However, any candidate having served a four-year apprenticeship in the construction, installation and repair of refrigerating machines is eligible to the examination of grade R-3.

57.—Examination of Diesel engine operators:—Candidates to this examination must be at least eighteen (18) years of age and have some knowledge concerning the construction and operation of Diesel-type internal combustion engines.

58.—Should the capacity of a plant be increased over the maximum corresponding to the class of the stationary engineman in charge, the latter shall, within a delay of ninety (90) days following the date of the increase, undergo the prescribed examination before the Board of Examiners, if eligible, and obtain the certificate of the class corresponding to the new capacity of the plant.

59.—The Board of Examiners may, in an emergency case, authorize a stationary engineman to replace, for a maximum period of thirty (30) days, the stationary engineman under whose direction he is working; at the expiration of this delay, this stationary engineman must obtain the certificate which will permit him to take charge of the plant, provided he be eligible to the prescribed examination.

60.—The Board of Examiners may, with the authorization of the Minister, diminish the apprenticeship period in each class for any person who has followed the courses of a known technical school or who is particularly qualified.

61.—No stationary engineman shall carry on occupations which may make him neglect his work or endanger the security of the plant; furthermore, no employer of any stationary engineman shall require the carrying on of such occupations.

62.—A stationary engineman shall not leave the engine room for more than fifteen (15) minutes unless being replaced by a stationary engineman holding a certificate of not more than one grade inferior to that required to take charge of the plant.
According to regulations page 4 b no certificate is required to take charge of a boiler with a safety valve set at a pressure of not more than 15 lbs with a capacity not exceeding 75 horse-power.
MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, March 14, 1949.

Re: 12-Room Indian Day School, Caughnawaga, Dormitory Block, Wabasca Indian School.

The sum of $330,000.00 was provided in the 1948-49 appropriations for the construction of a twelve room Indian Day School at Caughnawaga, boiler house included, of which $200,000.00 was transferred to our Division. We will require an additional amount ranging from $3,000.00 to $30,000.00 and will have the exact figure within a week from now. In the meantime it is necessary that Indian Affairs Branch be informed that our maximum total requirements in any event will be no more than $230,000.00 during the current fiscal season which will leave $100,000.00 of the original $330,000.00 for use elsewhere.

The Bond Construction Company Limited, contractors for the Wabasca Dormitory Block, estimate that their progress claims to March 31, 1949, will total $105,000.00 for the Dormitory Block alone. We have received $25,000.00 from the Indian Affairs Branch to date for this work and will require an additional $80,000.00 in the current fiscal season. We suggest that transfer of funds not required for the Caughnawaga project could be transferred to the Wabasca project.

It is essential that we be informed at an early date if the $80,000.00 we require for Wabasca will be made available in time to make the necessary payments to the contractor in the current fiscal season.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,

You will recall previous correspondence concerning our plans for converting the Caughnawaga Eastern School for use by the United Church children, when it is no longer required by the Roman Catholic children.

"Since the heating unit in the present United Church school will have to be changed; and since our Board of Home Missions must renew the heating unit in the church building this year; and since the heating unit in the minister's residence must be replaced within two to five years, therefore, we feel that there might be some way in which your Department and our Board of Home Missions could cooperate in installing a central heating unit for the three buildings.

"This suggestion is feasible due to the short distance between the buildings.

"As you know, it is less expensive to heat three buildings from one central unit than from three..."
units. The cost of operation to your Department, to the church, and to the house could be determined quite easily from the cubic content of each building.

By the time this would be done, Dr. Dorsey should have returned to Toronto and details of installation cost could be arranged between yourself and him."

When your engineer visits this school, we would appreciate his comments concerning the feasibility of Mr. Kennedy's suggestions.

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa, May 20, 1949.

Re: New Senior Day School,
Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Que.

In connection with the above, we advise that the progress in the construction has advanced to the point where it is thought advisable to have the Indian Affairs Branch issue purchase orders for the electrical cooking equipment for the school.

In planning the electrical system, we discussed the question of electric equipment for the kitchen with officers of the Indian Affairs Branch and equipment was selected most suited to the requirements.

We were advised that the Indian Affairs Branch had access to an apartment range and a refrigerator, details of which were furnished to our architects for use in laying out the kitchen.

It will be necessary to place orders for a large range to be primarily used for baking purposes and ten hot plates for use on the food preparation counter.

The following is the equipment to be purchased from Moffats Ltd., Weston, Ontario. The prices shown are subject to recent price changes not furnished to this Division and include sales tax of 5%, equipment f.o.b. Weston.

1. One only model 85 Moffat range with 2-1600 watt and 2-1200 watt boiling plates, 230 volts, single phase, 60 cycle otherwise as included under price List No. 29 in the amount of $370.00 less Department discount of 10% and 10%. Price to the Department, .................. $299.70

2. Ten only standard counter model H-13-1 hot plate with one 1200 watt boiling plate, 115 volt, single phase, 60 cycle otherwise as included under the price list No. 29 in the amount of $18.00 each; less Department discount of 10% and 10%. Price to the Department, .................. $145.00

We suggest that the orders for the above equipment be placed as soon as possible and a request for earliest possible delivery be made on the above items especially on the ten hot plates, as they must be mounted on the food preparation counter. At the time of ordering, we recommend that hot plate shop drawings be requested and sent to (this Division) so they can be forwarded to the general contractor in order that provision can be made for mounting and connecting up the units prior to delivery, thus eliminating the possibility of delay in fabrication of the food preparation counter.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Chas. H. Buck,
For Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

Re: Fire Alarm System - Twelve Class Room Indian Day School, Caughnawaga, Quebec

In reply to your memorandum of July 19th last in connection with the above, we suggest that Indian Agent Brisebois be requested to contact Mr. Rene Laberge, Director of Finance of the City of Lachine, and advise him that the proposal of the Spencer Electric Alarms Company contained in their letter to Mr. Laberge of June 27th last is acceptable to the Department.

We confirmed by telephone that their estimated installation price of $95.00 includes all electrical work necessary at the school and the Fire Station to connect the two buildings to their line.

Mr. Laberge in his letter to Major MacKay of July 8th last states that the City of Lachine could have the work carried out and charged to the Department; however we see no merit in this arrangement and suggest that Mr. Brisebois be instructed to make arrangements with the Company for having the work started at an early date.

It will be necessary to extend the school fire alarm system circuit to the entrance point of the line to the Fire Station, and we intend to have our electrical engineer discuss the best means of arranging this work with officers of the Company during a proposed trip to Caughnawaga in the near future, as a minimum amount of exposed wiring is desired and disfigurement of wall finishes is to be avoided.

Monsieur Donald Black, M.P.,
Aubry, P. Q.

Cher monsieur le Député:

Permettez-moi cette démarche au nom des familles de Canadiens-Français et Anglais qui résident actuellement sur la Réserve indienne, tolérés qu'ils y sont par le "Département", à cause de la crise du logement qui sévit encore, hélas!

On me dit que dans ces familles il y a bien au-delà de 75 enfants d'âge scolaire. Vous voyez déjà le problème, puisqu'ces enfants ne sont pas admis dans les écoles indiennes locales.

Le Gouvernement Provincial veut bien faire sa part en procurant le transport gratuit de ces enfants aux écoles situées en dehors de la réserve, et même, en se montrant prêt à payer des institutrices pour ces enfants s'il y avait lieu.

Mais ici se pose un second problème: Quelle municipalité va les prendre dans ses écoles?

Ville La Salle n'accepte que ceux qui ont déjà commencé là depuis au moins trois ans. Lachine est prête à en accepter un certain nombre, moyennant le prix de $4.00 par mois, ce qui est au-delà des moyens de la plupart des familles, généralement nombreuses et peu fortunées. Il y a aussi la paroisse de la Côte Ste-Catherine; mais leur école actuelle est trop petite et leur nouvelle école n'ouvrira pas avant janvier.

La seule solution serait de pouvoir ouvrir une école pour des enfants ici même sur la réserve, si un local pouvait être trouvé et si une sorte de Commission Scolaire pouvait être formée pour la durée du cas d'urgence.
Je laisse toutefois à votre initiative, tout en promettant mon appui à vos sages mesures, de trouver la meilleure solution à ce problème important pour l'avenir de ces enfants, dont un bon nombre ont déjà dépassé l'âge de 8 et 9 ans sans avoir encore eu les moyens d'aller à l'école, ni d'être initiés aux éléments de la religion. Un homme sans instruction, et surtout sans religion, tous l'admettent, est non seulement très incomplet, mais peut devenir un citoyen dangereux pour la société et un chrétien exposé à manquer sa destinée éternelle...

Confiant que vous donnerez à ce problème l'attention qu'il mérite et que Dieu vous aidera à lui trouver la solution la plus avantageuse pour tous, je demeure,

Votre très obligé,

Real Lalonde, S.J.

Cure de Caughnawaga.

POWER CONTRACT

Agreement made and entered into at — VALLEYFIELD, Que.

By and between — His Majesty the King, as represented by Mr. F. Brisebois, Superintendent of Indian Agency, Caughnawaga,

hereinafter called the PURCHASER, and THE SHAWINIGAN WATER & POWER COMPANY A Corporation having its chief place of business in the City of Montreal, P.Q., herein acting and represented by its duly authorized officer and hereinafter called the COMPANY.

Whereas the Purchaser is desirous of obtaining electric service for the operation of its plant at Caughnawaga Indian Reserve and

Whereas the Company is willing to supply such electric service under the terms and conditions hereinafter set forth.

NOW THEREFORE, the parties hereto mutually agree as follows:

1.—Term of Contract:—The term of this contract shall be one (1) year from date of connection and the contract shall continue in force thereafter until cancelled by either party upon the expiration of one month's written notice.

2.—Amount of power under contract:— Twenty (20) horse-power.
Minimum billing demand:— Seventy-five percent (75%) of the amount of power under contract.

3.—Point of delivery:— Three insulators installed on customer's school.

4.—Kind of current:— 60 cycles, 3 phase. Normal voltage: 270 volts.
The voltage variation not to exceed ten percent plus or minus, except at times of sudden load changes or in cases of emergency or accident.

5.—Use of power:— For meters only on customer's property.

6.—Rate:— One dollar ($1.00) per horse-power of maximum demand per month, plus One and eight tenths of a cent (1.8¢) per kilowatt-hour for the first 40 kilowatt-hours per horse-power of maximum demand per month, plus Nine tenths of a cent (0.9¢) per kilowatt-hour for the next 40 kilowatt-hours per horse-power of maximum demand per month, plus Three-tenths of a cent (0.3¢) per kilowatt-hour for the balance of consumption during the month.

7.—Minimum monthly payment:— One dollar ($1.00) for each horse-power of minimum billing demand.
GENERAL CONDITIONS

8.—Subsequent to the date of this contract, any taxes, dues, fees or other charges imposed by any taxing authority on the electric power or energy to be delivered or furnished hereunder, or on the gross revenues of the Company, to be derived therefrom, then, in addition to the payments stipulated to be made by the Purchaser, the Purchaser agrees that the Company may levy upon the amount of such taxes, dues, fees or other charges calculated with respect to and based upon the amount of electrical energy to be supplied and taken hereunder.

9.—All bills rendered under the terms of this contract shall become due and payable at the Company's nearest office within thirty days from the date of rendering.

10.—The Company agrees to supply only the amount of power contracted for herein and shall use diligence in providing a regular and uninterrupted service but does not guarantee a constant supply of electricity and shall not be liable for any damage which the Purchaser may sustain by reason of failure in the supply of electricity for any cause whatsoever. Should the Purchaser take power in excess of the amount of power under contract for three consecutive months, and should the Company determine to charge such additional power, then the amount of power under contract shall be increased accordingly upon written notice sent to the Purchaser by the Company.

11.—All appliances and apparatus located beyond the point of delivery shall be supplied by the Purchaser and the Company shall not be responsible for any loss or damage to such apparatus and shall incur no liability for damages that may be caused to persons or property due to high voltage electric current and/or the presence of its wires or equipment. The Purchaser agrees to pay for any damage due to any other cause whatsoever. If any appliance located beyond the point of delivery located on or in the property of the Purchaser shall be in default of the Purchaser and if damaged by other than ordinary wear and tear, the Purchaser shall pay the Company the cost of repairing or replacing the said apparatus.

12.—The maximum demand shall be established each month by an approved type of demand meter when the Purchaser's electrical installation is in excess of 15 horse-power. If the said installation amounts of 15 horse-power or less, the maximum demand shall be established by test from time to time, or shall be taken as the total rated capacity of the motors, apparatus, etc., connected to the circuit.

13.—The minimum monthly payment shall be made in consideration of the Purchaser's right to use the Company's electric service and the Purchaser agrees to make this payment whether he uses the service or not.

14.—It is agreed that 746 watts will constitute one horse-power.

15.—The following table shall be the maximum amount of power taken during the month at 85% lagging power factor and shall be calculated on the basis of 85% of the maximum kilowatt-amperes registered by the demand meter, but shall never be less than the minimum billing demand stipulated herein. The Purchaser agrees to take steps to correct a lagging power factor and equipment shall be so installed that when power is not being used it shall be completely disconnected from the power line.

16.—Before being connected to the Company's system the Purchaser's installation must be approved by the Provincial Inspection Authority and, therefore, the Purchaser agrees to obtain such approval. The Purchaser further agrees to use reasonable diligence in the operation of his apparatus in order to avoid any undue disturbance to the Company's Electric System and so that his total load shall be divided equally as possible between phases.

17.—The Purchaser shall provide a suitable location and also, when requested by the Company, a metal enclosure, approved by the Provincial Inspection Authority, for the installation of the Company's meter and metering transformers.

18.—The Purchaser hereby grants to the Company, without compensation for the use thereof, the right to construct power lines and necessary apparatus on locations approved by the Purchaser on, under or over its property whenever required for the purpose of serving it and other purchasers of power from the Company. Such lines shall be maintained therein at all times for the construction, repair, replacement or removal of the same provided that such lines shall at no time unduly interfere with the Purchaser's business or cause damage to its buildings or property.

19.—Special conditions:

All previous communications between the parties hereto are hereby abrogated and the present contract bearing the signature of the Purchaser constitutes the agreement between the parties hereto, after signature by the Company on the fifteenth day of July 1919.

The PURCHASER acknowledges having received a duplicate of the present contract.

THE SHAWINIGAN WATER & POWER COMPANY

Dear Sister Mary Mediatrix,

I believe that you are anxious to give the pupils in your lovely new and progressive school every advantage, and are considering employing a teacher for English Diction. I would be very happy to submit my application as teacher for such a course. You are quite familiar with my capabilities and the good response I get from my pupils.

I could follow the same programme I use in St. Angela's and St. Ann's Boarding Schools, which covers: diction, voice, speech and vocabulary; extemporaneous speaking; preparation and delivery of prepared speeches; parliamentary procedure; debating and round table discussions; Personality, poise and deportment; and in the lower grades; diction and elocution.

Altho I shall have classes in several other convents this year I feel sure that we can arrange a day suitable and convenient to both of us.

September 13, 1949

Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Division
Department of Mines and Resources
Indian Affairs Branch
OTTAWA

Dear Sir:

"Time and Tide wait for no man," but man simply must wait for Time and the things that come along with the Tide, such as estimates for approved requisitions. That is the only reason which explains the long delay of this letter—otherwise, it would have been written two days after Mr. Neary's visit on August 31.

Knowing that he would be absent for quite a while, he asked me to address all communications directly to you, as you were informed of all the doings in Caughnawaga and that you would see to their immediate and safe despatch.

There are several items to be covered—each one as important as the other—and the length of this letter is not meant to discourage you; on the contrary, I shall endeavour to set forth as clearly as possible the determining provisions considered in the preparation of the enclosed requisition. These may help you take appropriate decisions, knowing the local needs. Each point has already been discussed with and approved by Mr. Neary, but Form and Convenience exact that they be committed to writing.

Our beautiful new school eventually opened wide its doors to 330 pupils yesterday...but no one can say it is complete—there are ever so many indispensable details that must be attended to before the Official Opening, and even after. The old furniture really impairs the appearance of the spacious and well-lighted classrooms. That is why I am placing the furniture item first: lack of suitable desks and chairs for the teachers; pupils' desks (Mr. Neary has already ordered 120 desks, but at least 50 more will be needed—the exact number and size will be definitely determined as soon as the registration is complete);
bookcases for each room as there is none free to serve as library as had been previously planned; the entire equipment for the two Principals' offices—desks, chairs, files, bookcases, typewriters (the old ones are beyond repair), and desk lamps. In the meantime, the Department has had to spend a considerable sum for the repair and adaptation of old desks...

Mr. Neary asked me to obtain quotations from various firms for all the above articles. A separate tabulation of these prices is included for easy and quick comparison. Now for a few precisions...

The great variance in the price of the Principals' desks is rather striking: the Vilas Company offers a plain desk thereby necessitating a typewriting table, which in reality would be too large for the available office space; whereas the Valiquette Distributors Limited offer the convenient oak CLEMCO desks equipped with the typewriting-table inset—a piece of furniture that will outlive the school. Wouldn't you consider the present extra expense an actual saving?

The requisition cupboards to be built in the waiting room of the Principal's office and the three cupboards for the Domestic Science rooms are also indispensable articles that were definitely approved in June and in August. Valiquette Distributors quote the price for birch cupboards but they will actually be made of mahogany. (Mr. Racine has done his utmost to furnish reasonable prices for exceptional quality.) J. P. Dupuis' estimates cover the bare wooden element of the cupboards...no glass nor any other fixture.

We fully realize that equipping a new school as large as ours can cause a severe headache to the Personnel of the Purchasing Department. To offer them some sort of relief, we found our way to a well-known second-hand store: Baillargeon Furniture Galleries. They carry a good stock and therefore present worthwhile and tempting bargains. By the very fact that we become their customers, they accept any furniture we may have to discard. They repair and sell it at the most advantageous price, giving us 70% of the sale. Their stock is generally liquidated within a three-month period. The three items submitted by this Company are really good buys, and the credit received from the sale of our old furniture would yield a worthwhile decrease on the present expenditure.
Mr. Philip Phelan

Sept. 13, 1949

The sectional bookcases requested are for the two higher classes of the Boys' and Girls' sections... they could also be purchased in view of the future library. The plain glass-paneled cases from Vilas Company will do very well for the other rooms.

The other items of the requisition are all essential. They were not included in the April requisition simply because they could not be determined before the school was completed.

Another proposal which Mr. Neary readily sanctioned was the addition of a Public Speaking Instructor. Mrs. Dewar of Montreal has sent in her application to teach Public Speaking, Choral speaking and Elocution to our pupils. She would have to give eight lessons of one-half hour each for which she is charging the reasonable fee of $20. Her weekly lessons are well-prepared, practical, and delivered with a charming facility and simplicity that exercises a beneficial influence over the students. We know that the Department is willing to do all in its power to raise the level of better English and culture in all its forms for the benefit of the Indians and we dare vouchsafe for the successful work that Mrs. Dewar will accomplish with our pupils. As she would be ready to begin her work in October, the Department will no doubt advise us as soon as possible of her acceptance.

The letter in which you authorized us to spend $15 for Music Appreciation has been inadvertently lost.... May I disturb the Filing Department for a duplicate copy of it because the File Number is required for the Disbursement Voucher. It was received between July 15 and August 8. This favour will be greatly appreciated.

Sr. Mary Alma, Domestic Science Instructor, wishes to renew her request for the expenditure of the same monthly allowance, $13.50, for her Department. She is well-pleased with her new quarters so bright and spacious. The articles called for in the requisition will complete its practicality.

Now for The "Elementary Art" by R.W. Hedly requisitioned August 24 and for which Mr. Neary asked more detailed information. Each set covers Grades I including VIII, and we are asking for three sets—one for both Sections and one for the Office.

In my haste to return The Oaths yesterday, I overlooked Sister Dolores Marie's name on the list of retiring teachers from last year's staff. May I trouble you to advise the Treasury Department? Thank you.
Mr. Philip Phelan

Sept. 13, 1949

I trust that this long letter has served its purpose. It was written with the sole aim of offering you and Purchasing Department some enlightening explanations that would tip the Treasury Scales on the most economical side so that the least possible time may be lost in purchasing the equipment—and also not to delay the Official Opening announced for a probable date around mid-October.

The Department may well be very proud of its new acquisition (we are, too) and it would make your heart feel good to hear the appreciative exclamations of the numerous visitors from our own country and from the United States. We are most eager to see it completely equipped and to have the different Officials of the Department come to admire it.

Very truly yours,

[Signature]
Principal

September 15, 1949

Mr. Philip Phelan, Chief, Training Division

OTTAWA

Dear Mr. Phelan:

May I add a personal note to the already extra-long "business epistle" enclosed?

It is indeed a real pleasure for me, Mr. Phelan, to renew acquaintance with you (being an "old-Timer" of '30) and the pleasant, friendly relations you had with my worthy predecessors—Sisters Mary Cleophas and George Edmund, to name but two. How they would appreciate our beautiful new school! The Lord has reserved this pleasure for the latter only—and we hope it will be soon—the others are already enjoying the blessed fruits of their untiring labours.

Past correspondence reveals your deep interest in the welfare of our Indians, and your wholehearted, ever-ready cooperation reassures me in my dealings with the Department. Knowing the local needs, you will between the lines and understand the necessity of the different articles. I don't believe there is any extravagance—nevertheless, I did my best to find furniture that would be compatible with the "Pride of the Federal Government" and that would prevent doubling the expense in the future.

May I count on you for a speedy despatch of this requisition, as I figure that the Official Opening will not take place till everything is really ready.

We are most grateful to have to deal with such strong concerted interests and efforts as yours and Mr. Neary's.

With sincere appreciation,

[Signature]
Sister Mary Mediator
Principal

Dear Colonel Neary:

Since the pump began working after a delay of three days, the water situation though improved, is not of the best. Each afternoon, about two o'clock, the water gives out with all the resulting complications easy to imagine.

Problem No. 2, to my way of thinking, is the playground in back of the school. Only one softball or baseball team can play at the same time. Having more recesses would be unfeasible; there are already two different periods (1st-4th and 5th-9th grades) both in the morning and afternoon. I have been carefully over every foot of the place and with the exception of the spot where the boys play lacrosse or softball, it is a hazard. Holes, rocks, stumps, etc., spangle the field, so to speak. It will be a miracle if no accidents occur before the snow sets in. Whatever, under prevailing conditions, it is difficult to organize the sports here, as the children have a right to expect. "Where shall we play?" they ask. With Mr. Brisebois' help, I shall try to interest them—at least a good many of them—in volley-ball. That would ease up the situation for a while.

Doubtless in your spare time—if you have any—you must be wondering how the new staff at the Caughnawaga Day School is getting along. Rather well. The boys seem to have taken to the teachers. Thanks to a gift of a dozen new lacrosses from outsiders, we have a group of the bigger boys playing after school hours. Father Burns supervises the players who are the keymen ('boys) and they naturally react favorably in class.

Mr. Desmarais, now, this is a first impression, seems to be an excellent addition to the teaching staff.

Mr. Viau is doing well also. May I suggest that his first month's salary be forwarded to him as soon as possible? He has, as you know, a large family, six children, if I am not mistaken, and funds would indeed be welcome. I did not send in his application blank sooner (Sept. 12), as I waited quite a few days before I learned that Mr. Desmarais had sent his in through Mr. Brisebois.

Thanking you for all you are doing for Caughnawaga, I remain

Very gratefully yours,

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Heating System, New Senior School.

This is to report that the heating system at the above School is not working properly, this probably due to the fact that final adjustments have not yet been made by the Contractor.

Radiators in certain classes are overheating while in other rooms they remain cold, resulting in discomfort for all concerned and daily complaints from the teachers.

It would appear that the Contractor is expecting the visit of a Departmental engineer in connection with the heating and the ventilating system.

Has anything be done yet towards the appointment of a competent man to take charge of the above at that School?

(Frs. Brisebois)
Supt., Indian Agency.
Caughnawaga, Que.,
September 29, 1949.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Re:- Water supply, New Senior School.

I wish to report that the water supply at the above named School is very poor. The water pumped from the well into the basin is just sufficient to take care of the requirements for the forenoon on School days. Water is running short at about 2 hrs P.M., every day.

As you are aware there is a well located at about 350 feet from the Senior School. This well is supplying the Kateri School, presently occupied by the U.C. School, and tests made a few years ago revealed that there is a considerable volume of water available there.

It might be desirable to have further tests made for the same well with a view of running a pipe from same to the reservoir of the New School, if it is found that there is enough water to supply both buildings.

Of course this is a matter for the Engineers to determine but I would be pleased to be informed of your views in the matter. According to the Railway Power & Engineering Co., experts it would be relatively easy to pump water from that point with the proper equipment.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Supt., Indian Agency.

MEMORANDUM

Re: New Twelve Room Indian Day School, Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Quebec.

In reply to your notation dated the 7th instant on Major MacKay's memorandum of October 4th regarding a report that the heating system was not functioning properly at the above, you are advised that on the 10th instant, we contacted Mr. Payette, our inspecting architect for the project by telephone and instructed him to investigate the complaint and report to us that day.

Mr. Payette reported by long distance telephone as requested, advising that the acting engineer at the school was unfamiliar with the installation and that by correct valve regulation, equal heat distribution to all areas was obtained.

Our heating engineer, Mr. Hargreaves, recently visited Caughnawaga and inspected the installation. At that time the boilers had not been put into operation. We have in mind sending Mr. Hargreaves to Caughnawaga again, but had anticipated that Indian Affairs would have appointed a qualified permanent engineer to operate the mechanical services at the school, before he went.

Our Chief Architect in contacting Indian Affairs, has been advised that as yet no appointment has been made, but that the matter is receiving definite consideration at the moment.

There is no objection to Indian Affairs action in putting the boiler plant into operation temporarily under control of the fireman who services other schools in the agency, but within the next two weeks, we consider it advisable to have Mr. Hargreaves go to Caughnawaga and familiarize the operator with the technical needs of the system. A later trip for the benefit of the permanent appointee will be necessary.

Chief, Engineering and Construction Division.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

September 29, 1949

Mr. Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education
Department of Mines and Resources
Ottawa

Dear Sir:

Mr. Phelan informs me in his letter of September 20 that your return "Home" is scheduled for October 1. And here I am to welcome you with another epistle.... I trust that your visits to the different reserves are not so harassing as those to Caughnawaga....

The tenor of my letter of September 13 and the accompanying requisition must have stunned him. I fully agree with him that they were unusual—but then, our new school is a most unusual item in the Government's budget! I really do not want to be importunate, Mr. Neary; I am simply doing my best to equip this beautiful, modern construction with suitable furniture and various equipment that will convert the building into a real school, such as the Department desires. I assure you that extravagant selection was wilfully avoided, and many items were even postponed till next year. Because you had approved all these points, I felt quite free in exposing the several considerations involved.

We do not regret the time and trouble spent in "bargain-hunting" and in preparing the requisition as everything was done solely to carry out your orders, to save you precious time, and to facilitate your work as much as possible. Your discerning choice and decision in the matter will assuredly meet the requirements seeing that you are so familiar with the actual local needs.

Daily living in the new school affords enlightening experiences. I hope this one will not disappoint you too much. Contrary to the regular routine followed for the Official Openings, it will be impossible for us to carry out the program in the school should the weather be stormy—the pupils alone would occupy three-fourths of the corridor, leaving no place for the activities nor for the invited guests. Such a late date would practically prohibit an outside performance—the cold weather would play havoc with the current pre-dispositions for T.E.
The next best thing that remains to be done is having the entire program executed at Kateri Hall, which Father Lalonde graciously offered. We have already adapted our activities to this staging, presuming that you would not have any objections. The lunch would be served at school after the official visiting.

Mrs. McComber informs me that the dishes used at the Home-Makers' Convention three years ago were rented from Mr. Bergeron, Lachine, at a very nominal price. Would you want us to solicit the same favour, or would you prefer that we buy our own dishes? The Club had not purchased any for the simple reason that they had no place to keep them since they have no special quarters at their disposal.

Another point which I would like you to clarify is the amount allowed to cover the incurring expenses of such a ceremony. Last August you said that the Department generally allows $75. Now, according to our calculations, the cost of a light lunch for the invited guests plus at least two representatives from about 200 families that send their children to school would easily exceed that amount. Our past experience with Alumnae gatherings proves that expenses range from 30¢ to 40¢ per capita. If the demonstration takes place on a Saturday afternoon or a Sunday, more people will want to witness it. Of course, this number excludes our 350 pupils, who will enjoy their share the following day.

The increase becomes quite obvious when we compare our 12-classroom school with those of four or even six rooms. It is only logical that the expenses would double too. Therefore, the lowest calculation would necessitate $150.... May I ask you to stamp this point with your seal of approbation in your next letter?

Sr. Phelan's letter of September 26 inquires about the Application Form from Sr. Dorothy Marie--name mistaken no doubt for Sr. Dolores Marie. The last paragraph on Page 3 of my letter dated September 13 explains the omission: she is replaced by Sr. Mary Cabrini.

It is rather unusual that the books from the requisition you sent to the Purchasing Department at the end of August have not yet arrived. We are in urgent need of these texts as these important subjects--Religion and Literature--carry quite a heavy program. A good deal of the April requisition is still on the waiting list....

I am most eager to receive an answer to my long epistles, which I honestly hope did not cause you too severe a headache. Your reply will also bring us more information concerning the definite date of the Official Opening....
It will be more than time to send out the invitations. Our Printing Shop in Lachine charges $3.50 C for handset printing and $2.00 C for machine-set printing. If it is agreeable to you, we could have the invitations for the guests of honor done there. The others would receive theirs through the pulpit and through the children.

There are ever so many question marks popping up concerning the functioning of the new school that you may decide to come to answer them "viva voce." That would be a splendid solution and a real time-saver. You did leave us to our own initiative, but your approbation of certain points is necessary to dispel any doubt we may entertain as to their feasibility.

Very appreciatively yours,

[Signature]
Principal, Girls' Section

P. S. Mr. Brisebois informed me today that the Henderson Company from St. Lambert will deliver the desks you ordered at the end of next week. We are eager to see them.

Caughnawaga R.C., Indian Day School.

I have for answer your recent letters concerning your requirements at the Caughnawaga School and also those of the Sister Superior.

With regard to the playground, please speak to Mr. Brisebois about this as he has been in touch with a company which may submit a tender.

We simply do not have enough funds to buy additional new desks for the school unless it can be proved that the present ones are unserviceable. The funds asked for by the Sister Superior are simply not available until the water situation at the school is decided. Until we know how much additional money is required to locate water, we must be very careful in buying new equipment as otherwise there will not be enough money to cover the water supply.

The same situation applies with regard to the road leading to the school. We can do little on this road until it has been decided as to what the water situation will be and whether a pipeline will have to be laid from the river up to the school. If so, this line will pass directly through where we intend to lay a proper road to the school.

You can advise the Sister Superior that action is being taken to provide certain of the requirements for desks, etc., but that some items will definitely have to wait until I know where we stand with regard to the water. I am pleased to note that the new desks which have arrived are satisfactory.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

As you are aware we received the visit of Mr. Hargreaves, Engineer of the Engineering and Construction Division of the Dept., of Mines and Resources, who arranged to have Mr. Paul Perron, Water Locator of Rosemere, Que., visit the School site with a view of finding suitable sites for further drilling.

Mr. Perron visited the School site on this date and found that water could be obtained at two different places. Herewith enclosed is the original of his report in the French language and a translation of same made at this office.

Mr. Hargreaves happened to be present when Mr. Perron stated his work and he will remember that two particular spots were worked by Mr. Perron. What is described as Well No. 1, is that location on the east side of the School yard, where there are several large uncovered rocks.

Well No. 2, is located south west of the yard in a rather flat area. This well should yield about 8 gallons per minute while No. 1 would produce more. Mr. Perron is quite positive about his findings although he states that the area surrounding the School is not favorable to high producing wells.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources.

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st., ultimo, dealing with the winter opening of the St. Isidore Road, so that our School children may be able to travel by Bus to the Village schools.

After discussions with the Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies, this matter was taken up with the Provincial authorities, when it was suggested that they undertake the work themselves with the understanding that we would contribute an amount of $75.00 per mile.

On that occasion I was told that this matter would have to be discussed further between the local representative of the Provincial Government and the higher authorities.

I am now advised that it will not be possible at least for the coming winter for the Provincial to undertake the clearing of this road as they will be maintaining Winter Roads for the benefit of the Municipalities of St. Isidore through to St. Philomene, to the main Montreal-Malone Highway. St. Isidore Junction will have their road through St. Constant, Delson and Laprairie for them to reach Montreal. Furthermore it is claimed that the Budget for the maintenance of winter roads did not provide for the opening of St. Isidore road for this winter.

It would appear that the only way to keep this road open would be for us to hire snowploughs locally.

Over.
In this regard I have to advise that the services of two different companies would be available as follows; Jean Bedard Ltd., of Caughnawaga and Ville LaSalle who are operating three snowploughs and who are doing work for the town of LaSalle, the town of St. Pierre and who have also kept our Village streets open for the past two years. Their hourly price for a snow-plough and two men are of $6.00 per working hour including Sundays and holidays.

The other firm would be the Quinlan Cut Stone Co. of Ville LaSalle who are the owners of one snowplough. Their rates are of $6.00 per hour for weekdays and of $75.00 per hour for Sundays and holidays, also for Saturday afternoons after 12:00 P.M.

None of these firms are willing to undertake the work on a mileage basis.

As you may be aware it is impossible to make an exact estimate of such an undertaking as it depends entirely on weather conditions.

For instance our Village streets (about 3½ miles) were kept open last winter for the sum of $280.00, while the previous winter amounted to over $500.00.

Will you kindly advise if it would be in order for us to make arrangements locally for the clearing of St. Isidore Road on an hourly basis.

Fr. Brisebois,
Superintendent.

Re: Water supply for Caughnawaga Indian Day School.

We understand that some difficulty is being encountered in securing sufficient water for the operation of the school from the present source of supply.

It has been suggested that the St. Lawrence River be considered as a possible new source. Recently we were asked to prepare a 5-year plan, and an item of $200,000.00 was included in the 5-year plan for the years 1953-54 and 1954-55. It is not likely that $200,000.00 will be sufficient to pay for a water supply for the Indian village, but perhaps it would be sufficient to make a start on the work.

If the provision of a water supply from the St. Lawrence River is being considered for the school, it might be well to consider the Indian village needs at the same time and a sufficiently large intake and main pipe line be specified to take care of both the school and the village.

I would suggest, therefore, that your engineer be asked to furnish us with an estimate of the cost of providing a water supply system from the St. Lawrence River that will provide sufficient water for the school and will permit extension to provide water for the Indian village.

In preparing this report, we would ask that the engineer break down the costs and show what should be charged to the Indian Education Vote and what to the Indian Agencies Vote.

MEMORANDUM TO THE DIRECTOR

Water Supply for Caughnawaga Indian Day School.

With reference to your notation on a memorandum dated the 15th instant from the Director, Indian Affairs Branch, it is noted that Major MacKay requests an engineer's report covering the estimated cost of providing a water supply system from the St. Lawrence River that will supply the needs of the above school and will permit an extension to meet the requirements of the Indian Village.

The construction of such a water supply system is considered to be a major undertaking and, before an estimate can be given that would be fairly accurate, it will be necessary to carry out surveys and investigations on the ground. Provided the snow conditions remain satisfactory it is expected that such a survey could be carried out during the month of January and after a tentative design is drawn up it is expected that the report could be prepared by the end of February. If, however, an approximate estimate only is required, it is expected that same could be prepared for Major MacKay shortly after the first of January.

In the meantime our engineers wish to be advised if it is the intention of the Indian Affairs Branch to supply a quantity of water sufficient for fire-fighting purposes together with hydrants placed throughout the village to provide for fire protection.

We would appreciate your further instructions regarding this matter.

Memorandum to the Director

New Twelve-roomed Indian Day School,
Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Quebec.

A memorandum to you from the Director, Indian Affairs Branch, dated the 9th of January and carrying your notation of the 10th instant requests information regarding the action this Branch proposes to take, relative to loosened mortar in brickwork at the above, to which his attention had been drawn by Mr. Doucet, following a visit to the Agency with Mr. Kosnar on the 29th of December.

Mr. Doucet's observation to Major MacKay, that some brickwork was faulty and would have to be replaced is in error. The explanation of the situation is, that to accomplish occupancy of the school by the beginning of the fall term in 1949, the Contractors were instructed to continue construction operations throughout the winter. It was apparent to our Chief Architect when in company with Col. Neary he inspected the school last fall, that the coping stones had been pointed with mortar affected by frost, since bed and end joints had deteriorated. On Mr. Buck's instructions the Contractors re-pointed the copings and applied a transparent waterproofing compound which seemed to check any further deterioration was evident in brick jointing at that time, but when Mr. Kosnar reported the matter following his return from Caughnawaga, it was taken up with Mr. Gege, President of the Pyers Construction Co., who has agreed to have all brickwork in the walls examined and to re-point jointing where necessary, as soon as the danger of frost is over, at no cost to the Department.

No purpose would be served by an analysis of the mortar chips brought back by Mr. Kosnar.

Chief.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your favor of the 15th instant you are apparently in error as regards to our rates.

The rates of 15 cents less 10% as stipulated in the paragraph A. is subject to the condition that we have a street lighting contract for not less than 50 lamps.

It is stipulated in the agreement between the Department and ourselves that in the event we do not get the street lighting contract of not less than 50 lamps, we may charge 17¢ less 15% per K.W. hour.

Thus far, we have not got the contract for the street lighting and therefore we avail ourselves of the privilege of charging the higher rate, as mentioned in the contract submitted, until such time as we obtain the said contract for the street lighting.

Trusting we have explained the matter to your complete satisfaction.

Yours very truly,

SUBJECT: The terms and conditions of this application which refers to the premises in approval for, and such other premises as may be endorsed hereon, are agreed to form part hereof, the subscriber, the United Power Company, Limited, its successors and assigns hereinafter referred to as "the Company," agrees to supply electric service to the Consumer at the premises mentioned before or such other premises as may be approved by the Company from time to time, and the Consumer may from time to time remove during the period mentioned or any renewal thereof, the premises approved herein.

The Consumer agrees to pay to the Company weekly or bi-weekly, in advance, the amount of the bill rendered by the office, within ten days of receipt thereof, and to keep the premises free from all charges or meters to be installed by the Company in Consumer's premises, and to allow the Company to enter upon the premises for the purpose provided, if accounts are paid within ten days of their date.

In the event of failure to pay the bill within three (3) consecutive months, at any time or at any premises, without any second notice, the Company reserves the right to notify the Consumer of the fact in writing.

GENERAL CONDITIONS.

1. Should any meter fail to register accurately the Company may substitute another meter and charge for the service supplied until such failure is corrected. The consumption during the period indicated or on the basis of the consumption during the corresponding period in the preceding year shall constitute the basis for the rate charged or evidence.

2. No changes or additions to the installation shall be made by the Consumer after the same has been connected with the Company's system except by written permission of the Company.

3. If at any time there is a change in the premises, it is hereby agreed the Consumer will notify the Company in writing of such change.

4. The Company shall, in the supply of the service contracted for, make no representation regarding the nature or quality of the service, and shall not be liable for any damage caused by any apparatus or premises whether through failure of any of its apparatus or otherwise.

5. The Company does not guarantee the safety of the property and shall not be liable for any damages to the Consumer in consequence of any failure of the Company's apparatus.

6. In case the Company cancels this contract or discontinues its service, the Consumer agrees to pay the Company the amount applicable thereto as stipulated herein, and the Consumer agrees to pay the equivalent thereof covered by this contract for each month and fraction of a month thereafter.

7. This contract shall be transferred to and continued at any new location occupied by the Consumer, and the Consumer agrees to pay the equivalent thereof covered by this contract for each month and fraction of a month thereafter.

PERIOD OF CONTRACT AND ITS CANCELLATION.

The period of contract and its cancellation shall constitute a contract between the Company and the Consumer from year to year until terminated by notice in writing by either party given thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the period of contract or any year thereafter, subject, in the case of notice by the Consumer, to the satisfaction of the Company.

In the event of the consumer vacating the premises to which service is being supplied, the Consumer agrees to give thirty (30) days' notice to the Company, and the Company agrees to supply service to the Consumer's premises until such written notice shall have been received by the Company.

No representations, promises or agreements shall be binding upon the Company unless the same have been incorporated herein.

We have never received any complaints from anybody else in regard to our men at Delson, who is known to us as an exceptionally polite young man, always obliging to us and to our customers.

As to the service it is the same as at Delson, and we have had no complaints from that Village. We have had one or two short interruptions due to causes beyond our control, such as the breaking of trees due to lightning and to wind storms, also a few interruptions due to the Montreal Light Heat & Power Co., from whom we obtain our power for distribution. This latter Company was obliged to shut off the power quite a lot this summer to make certain repairs due to serious damage to their transmission line last spring.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your favor of the 4th instant we find the electric meter and service wires much too small to serve the 5 H.P. motor you have installed at the teacher's residence at Caughnawaga, and if used may burn out the meter. The present use of same is therefore entirely at your risk.

We beg to submit for your kind consideration 2 proposals for the power supply, as follows:

Proposal No. 1. This contemplates joint use of power and light on same meter, paying for power same rate as for light, viz. 17 cents less 15%. Contract is for one year.

Proposal No. 2. This is a 3 year contract for power only, rate 5 cents net per K.W.hour with a minimum guarantee of $1.00 per H.P. per month, in this case $5.25 min. per month, with meter rental for special meter of 25 cents per month. In this case arrangement must be made by you for the placing of the Company's meter, similarly as was done for the electric light supply.

We have no such large meters in stock, so perhaps you will be good enough to write or to wire at once, which proposal you wish to accept, so that we can order the meter at once and make the changes with the least possible delay.

Whether it will be safe to use the motor in the meantime will depend on the actual load the motor is taking. If it is taking only about 3 H.P. and used in daytime only with no lights burning it should be safe enough. The ½ H.P. for the oil burner can be used in any case.

We shall install meter and wires large enough to take care of the extra ½ H.P. motor you may decide to install later on.

Trusting we have made ourselves clear and thanking you for the business,

Yours very truly,

C. Brandt

Gentlemen:

Since accepting your order for a Delco-Light pump to be installed at the Teacher's residence at Caughnawaga, we have sent a man to inspect the water system actually in use; he has found a hand pump down the cellar and an entirely separate water system with the source of supply from the neighboring priest's residence.

Your quotation blank led us to believe that a complete water system of some kind was in use in the building, which would have necessitated nothing but the cutting of the water pipe and making the connections to our pump. As it is, a real plumping job has to be done, requiring about 20 feet of piping and $3.00 or $4.00 worth of fixtures and connections.

We sincerely believe that you were not aware of these conditions and also we intend carrying this job through, we believe that in fairness, you should allow us some extra for doing this work. Thanking you in advance for a letter at your convenience, we beg you to believe us,
